The user is not required to resample if the superintendent monitors at the user's facility at least once a month, or if the superintendent samples between the user's initial sampling and when the user receives the results of this sampling. 
(i)  Notification of the discharge of hazardous waste. 
(1)  Any user who commences the discharge of hazardous waste shall notify the POTW, the EPA regional waste management division director, and state hazardous waste authorities, in writing, of any discharge into the POTW of a substance which, if otherwise disposed of, would be a hazardous waste under 40 CFR 261. Such notification must include the name of the hazardous waste as set forth in 40 CFR 261, the EPA hazardous waste number, and the type of discharge (continuous, batch, or other). If the user discharges more than 100 kilograms of such waste per calendar month to the POTW, the notification also shall contain the following information to the extent such information is known and readily available to the user: an identification of the hazardous constituents contained in the wastes, an estimation of the mass and concentration of such constituents in the wastestream discharged during that calendar month, and an estimation of the mass of constituents in the wastestream expected to be discharged during the following 12 months. All notifications must take place no later than 180 days after the discharge commences. Any notification under this subsection need be submitted only once for each hazardous waste discharged. However, notifications of changed conditions must be submitted under subsection (e) of this section. The notification requirement in this section does not apply to pollutants already reported by users subject to categorical pretreatment standards under the self-monitoring requirements of subsections (a), (b), (c) and (d) of this section. 
(2)  Dischargers are exempt from the requirements of subsection (i)(1) of this section during a calendar month in which they discharge no more than 15 kilograms of hazardous wastes, unless the wastes are acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e). Discharge of more than 15 kilograms of nonacute hazardous wastes in a calendar month, or of any quantity of acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e), requires a one-time notification. Subsequent months during which the user discharges more than such quantities of any hazardous waste do not require additional notification. 
(3)  In the case of any new regulations under Section 3001 of RCRA identifying additional characteristics of hazardous waste or listing any additional substance as a hazardous waste, the user must notify the superintendent, the EPA regional waste management waste division director, and state hazardous waste authorities of the discharge of such substance within 90 days of the effective date of such regulations. 
(4)  In the case of any notification made under this section, the user shall certify that it has a program in place to reduce the volume and toxicity of hazardous wastes generated to the degree it has determined to be economically practical. 
(5)  This provision does not create a right to discharge any substance not otherwise permitted to be discharged by this article, a permit issued thereunder, or any applicable federal or state law. 
(j)  Analytical requirements. All pollutant analyses, including sampling techniques, to be submitted as part of a wastewater discharge permit application or report shall be performed in accordance with the techniques prescribed in 40 CFR 136, unless otherwise specified in an applicable categorical pretreatment standard. If 40 CFR 136 does not contain sampling or analytical techniques for the pollutant in question, sampling and analyses must be performed in accordance with procedures approved by EPA. 
(k)  Sample collection. 
(1)  Except as indicated in subsection (k)(2) of this section, the user must collect wastewater samples using flow proportional composite collection techniques. In the event flow proportional sampling is infeasible, the superintendent may authorize the use of time proportional sampling or a minimum of four grab samples where the user demonstrates that this will provide a representative sample of the effluent being discharged. In addition, grab samples may be required to show compliance with instantaneous discharge limits. 
(2)  Samples for oil and grease, temperature, pH, cyanide, phenols, sulfides, and volatile organic compounds must be obtained using grab collection techniques. 
(l)  Timing. Written reports will be deemed to have been submitted on the date postmarked. For reports which are not mailed, postage prepaid, into a mail facility serviced by the United States Postal Service, the date of receipt of the report shall govern. 
(m)  Record keeping. Users subject to the reporting requirements of this article shall retain, and make available for inspection and copying, all records of information obtained pursuant to any monitoring activities required by this article and any additional records of information obtained pursuant to monitoring activities undertaken by the user independent of such requirements. Records shall include the date, exact place, method, and time of sampling, and the name of the person taking the samples; the dates analyses were performed; who performed the analyses; the analytical techniques or methods used; and the results of such analyses. These records shall remain available for a period of at least three years. This period shall be automatically extended for the duration of any litigation concerning the user or the city, or where the user has been specifically notified of a longer retention period by the superintendent. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.110) 
Sec. 98-162. - Compliance monitoring. 
(a)  Right of entry for inspection and sampling. The director of utilities shall have the right to enter the premises of any user to determine whether the user is complying with all requirements of this article and any wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder. Users shall allow the director of utilities ready access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination and copying, and the performance of any additional duties. 
(1)  Where a user has security measures in force which require proper identification and clearance before entry into its premises, the user shall make necessary arrangements with its security guards so that, upon presentation of suitable identification, the director of utilities will be permitted to enter without delay for the purposes of performing specific responsibilities. 
(2)  The director of utilities shall have the right to set up on the user's property, or require installation of, such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of the user's operations. 
(3)  The director of utilities may require the user to install monitoring equipment as necessary. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the user at its own expense. All devices used to measure wastewater flow and quality shall be calibrated at six-month intervals to ensure their accuracy. 
(4)  Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the user at the written or verbal request of the director of utilities and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the user. 
(5)  Unreasonable delays in allowing the director of utilities access to the user's premises shall be a violation of this article. 
(b)  Search warrants. If the director of utilities has been refused access to a building, structure, or property, or any part thereof, and is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this article, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program of the city designed to verify compliance with this article or any permit or order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health, safety and welfare of the community, then the director of utilities may seek issuance of a search warrant from the circuit court of the county. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.120) 
Sec. 98-163. - Confidential information. 
    Information and data on a user obtained from reports, surveys, wastewater discharge permit applications, wastewater discharge permits, and monitoring programs, and from the director of utilities' inspection and sampling activities, shall be available to the public without restriction, unless the user specifically requests, and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the director of utilities, that the release of such information would divulge information, processes, or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets under applicable state law. Any such request must be asserted at the time of submission of the information or data. When requested and demonstrated by the user furnishing a report that such information should be held confidential, the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public, but shall be made available immediately upon request to governmental agencies for uses related to the NPDES program or pretreatment program, and in enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics and other "effluent data" as defined by 40 CFR 2.302 will not be recognized as confidential information and will be available to the public without restriction. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.130) 
Sec. 98-164. - Publication of names of users in significant noncompliance. 
    The director of utilities shall publish annually, in the largest daily newspaper published in the municipality where the POTW is located, a list of the users which, during the previous 12 months, were in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. The term "significant noncompliance" shall mean: 
(1)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined here as those in which 66 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken during a six-month period exceed the daily maximum limit or average limit for the same pollutant parameter by any amount; 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined here as those in which 33 percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a six-month period equals or exceeds the product of the daily maximum limit or the average limit multiplied by the applicable criteria (1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oils and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); 
(3)  Any other discharge violation that the director of utilities believes has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through, including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public; 
(4)  Any discharge of pollutants that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment, or has resulted in the director of utilities' exercise of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within 90 days of the scheduled date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide, within 30 days after the due date, any required reports, including baseline monitoring reports, reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadlines, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or 
(8)  Any other violations which the director of utilities determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.140) 
Sec. 98-165. - Administrative enforcement remedies. 
(a)  Notification of violation. When the director of utilities finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the director of utilities may serve upon that user a written notice of violation. Within ten working days of the receipt of this notice, an explanation of the violation and a plan for the satisfactory correction and prevention thereof, to include specific required actions, shall be submitted by the user to the director of utilities. Submission of this plan in no way relieves the user of liability for any violations occurring before or after receipt of the notice of violation. Nothing in this section shall limit the authority of the director of utilities to take any action, including emergency actions or any other enforcement action, without first issuing a notice of violation. 
(b)  Consent orders. The director of utilities may enter into consent orders, assurances of voluntary compliance, or other similar documents establishing an agreement with any user responsible for noncompliance. Such documents will include specific action to be taken by the user to correct the noncompliance within a time period specified by the document. Such documents shall have the same force and effect as the administrative orders issued pursuant to subsections (d) and (e) of this section and shall be judicially enforceable. 
(c)  Show cause hearing. The director of utilities may order a user which has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, to appear before the director of utilities and show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. Notice shall be served on the user specifying the time and place for the meeting, the proposed enforcement action, the reasons for such action, and a request that the user show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. The notice of the meeting shall be served personally or by registered or certified mail (return receipt requested) at least 15 days prior to the hearing. Such notice may be served on any authorized representative of the user. A show cause hearing shall not be a bar against, or prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(d)  Compliance orders. When the director of utilities finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the director of utilities may issue an order to the user responsible for the discharge directing that the user come into compliance within a specified time. If the user does not come into compliance within the time provided, sewer service may be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices, or other related appurtenances are installed and properly operated. Compliance orders also may contain other requirements to address the noncompliance, including additional self-monitoring and management practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants discharged to the sewer. A compliance order may not extend the deadline for compliance established for a pretreatment standard or requirement, nor does a compliance order relieve the user of liability for any violation, including any continuing violation. Issuance of a compliance order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(e)  Cease and desist orders. When the director of utilities finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, or that the user's past violations are likely to recur, the director of utilities may issue an order to the user directing it to cease and desist all such violations and directing the user to: 
(1)  Immediately comply with all requirements; and 
(2)  Take such appropriate remedial or preventive action as may be needed to properly address a continuing or threatened violation, including halting operations and/or terminating the discharge. Issuance of a cease and desist order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(f)  Administrative fines. 
(1)  When the director of utilities finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the director of utilities may fine such user in an amount not to exceed the maximum penalties and fines authorized under applicable state and municipal state and federal laws. Such fines shall be assessed on a per violation, per day basis. In the case of monthly or other long-term average discharge limits, fines shall be assessed for each day during the period of violation. 
(2)  Unpaid charges, fines, and penalties shall, after 30 calendar days, be assessed an additional penalty of ten percent of the unpaid balance, and interest shall accrue thereafter at a rate of 1.5 percent per month. The director of utilities reserves the right to place a lien against the property in violation for unpaid charges, fines, and penalties. 
(3)  Users desiring to dispute such fines must file a written request for the director of utilities to reconsider the fine along with full payment of the fine amount within 30 days of being notified of the fine. Where a request has merit, the director of utilities may convene a hearing on the matter. In the event the user's appeal is successful, the payment, together with any interest accruing thereto, shall be returned to the user. The director of utilities may add the costs of preparing administrative enforcement actions, such as notices and orders, to the fine. 
(4)  Issuance of an administrative fine shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(g)  Emergency suspensions. The director of utilities may immediately suspend a user's discharge, after informal notice to the user, whenever such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge which reasonably appears to present or cause an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons. The director of utilities may also immediately suspend a user's discharge, after notice and opportunity to respond, that threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW, or which presents, or may present, an endangerment to the environment. 
(1)  Any user notified of a suspension of its discharge shall immediately stop or eliminate its contribution. In the event of a user's failure to immediately comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the director of utilities may take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW, its receiving stream, or endangerment to any individuals. The director of utilities may allow the user to recommence its discharge when the user has demonstrated to the satisfaction of the director of utilities that the period of endangerment has passed, unless the termination proceedings in subsection (h) of this section are initiated against the user. 
(2)  A user that is responsible, in whole or in part, for any discharge presenting imminent endangerment shall submit a detailed written statement, describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence, to the director of utilities prior to the date of any show cause or termination hearing under subsections (c) and (h) of this section. 
Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as requiring a hearing prior to any emergency suspension under this section. 
(h)  Termination of discharge. In addition to the provisions in section 98-160(f), any user who violates the following conditions is subject to discharge termination: 
(1)  Violation of wastewater discharge permit conditions; 
(2)  Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; 
(3)  Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater volume, constituents, and characteristics prior to discharge; 
(4)  Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection, monitoring, or sampling; or 
(5)  Violation of the pretreatment standards in section 98-152. 
Such user will be notified of the proposed termination of its discharge and be offered an opportunity to show cause under subsection (c) of this section why the proposed action should not be taken. Exercise of this option by the director of utilities shall not be a bar to, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.150) 
Sec. 98-166. - Judicial enforcement remedies. 
(a)  Injunctive relief. When the director of utilities finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the director of utilities may petition the county circuit court through the city attorney for the issuance of a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific performance of the wastewater discharge permit, order, or other requirement imposed by this article on activities of the user. The director of utilities may also seek such other action as is appropriate for legal and/or equitable relief, including a requirement for the user to conduct environmental remediation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. 
(b)  Civil penalties. 
(1)  A user who has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall be liable to the city for a maximum civil penalty of $1,000.00 per violation, per day. In the case of a monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of the violation. 
(2)  The director of utilities may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, and other expenses associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred by RMU. 
(3)  In determining the amount of civil liability, the court shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through the user's violation, corrective actions by the user, the compliance history of the user, and any other factor as justice requires. 
(4)  Filing a suit for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. 
(c)  Criminal prosecution. 
(1)  A user who willfully or negligently violates any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine, up to the maximum allowed under state law, per violation, per day, or imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. 
(2)  A user who willfully or negligently introduces any substance into the POTW which causes personal injury or property damage shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and be subject to a penalty of at least the maximum fine allowable under state law, or be subject to imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. This penalty shall be in addition to any other cause of action for personal injury or property damage available under state law. 
(3)  A user who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or certifications in any application, record, report, plan, or other documentation filed, or required to be maintained, pursuant to this article, wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine, up to the maximum fine allowable under state law, per violation, per day, or imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. 
(4)  In the event of a second conviction, a user shall be punished by a fine, up to the maximum fine allowable under state law per violation, per day, or imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. 
(d)  Remedies nonexclusive. The remedies provided for in this article are not exclusive. The director of utilities may take any, all, or any combination of these actions against a noncompliant user. Enforcement of pretreatment violations will generally be in accordance with RMU's enforcement response plan. However, the director of utilities may take other action against any user when the circumstances warrant. Further, the director of utilities is empowered to take more than one enforcement action against any noncompliant user. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.160) 
Sec. 98-167. - Supplemental enforcement actions. 
(a)  Performance bonds. The director of utilities may decline to issue or reissue a wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with any provision of this article, a previous wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, unless such user first files a satisfactory bond, payable to the city, in a sum not to exceed a value determined by the director of utilities to be necessary to achieve consistent compliance. 
(b)  Liability insurance. The director of utilities may decline to issue or reissue a wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with any provision of this article, a previous wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, unless the user first submits proof that it has obtained financial assurances sufficient to restore or repair damage to the POTW caused by its discharge. 
(c)  Water supply severance. Whenever a user has violated or continues to violate any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, water service to the user may be severed. Service will only recommence, at the user's expense, after it has satisfactorily demonstrated its ability to comply. 
(d)  Public nuisances. A violation of any provision of this article, a wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, is hereby declared a public nuisance and shall be corrected or abated as directed by the director of utilities. Any persons creating a public nuisance shall be subject to the provisions of this Code governing such nuisances, including reimbursing RMU for any costs incurred in removing, abating, or remedying said nuisance. 
(e)  Informant rewards. The director of utilities may pay up to $500.00 for information leading to the discovery of noncompliance by a user. 
(f)  Ineligibility for city contracts. Users which have not achieved compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements are not eligible to receive a contractual award for the sale of goods or services to the city. Existing contracts for the sale of goods or services to the city held by a user found to be in significant noncompliance with pretreatment standards or requirements may be terminated by the city at the recommendation of the director of utilities. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.170) 
Sec. 98-168. - Affirmative defenses to discharge violations. 
(a)  Upset. 
(1)  For the purposes of this section, the term "upset" means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
(2)  An upset shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards if the requirements of subsection (a)(3) of this section are met. 
(3)  A user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset shall demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs, or other relevant evidence that: 
a.  An upset occurred and the user can identify the causes of the upset; 
b.  The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and workmanlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance procedures; and 
c.  The user has submitted the following information to the superintendent within 24 hours of becoming aware of the upset if this information is provided orally, a written submission must be provided within five days: 
1.  A description of the indirect discharge and cause of noncompliance. 
2.  The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times or, if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to continue. 
3.  Steps being taken and/or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence of the noncompliance. 
4.  In any enforcement proceeding, the user seeking to establish the occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof. 
5.  Users will have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards. 
6.  Users shall control production of all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility is reduced, lost, or fails. 
(b)  Prohibited discharge standards. A user shall have an affirmative defense to an enforcement action brought against it for noncompliance with the general prohibitions in section 98-152(f)(1) or the specific prohibitions in section 98-152(f)(2)c.-h. and j.-r. if it can prove that it did not know, or have reason to know, that its discharge, alone or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would cause pass through or interference and that either: 
(1)  A local limit exists for each pollutant discharged and the user was in compliance with each limit directly prior to, and during, the pass through or interference; or 
(2)  No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change substantially in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when the POTW was regularly in compliance with its NPDES permit, and in the case of interference, was in compliance with applicable sludge use or disposal requirements. 
(c)  Bypass. 
(1)  For the purposes of this section: 
    Bypass means the intentional diversion of wastestreams from any portion of a user's treatment facility. 
    Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which can reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
(2)  A user may allow any bypass to occur which does not cause pretreatment standards or requirements to be violated, but only if it also is for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses are not subject to the provisions of subsections (c)(3) and (4) of this section. 
(3)  a.  If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it shall submit prior notice to the superintendent, at least ten days before the date of the bypass, if possible. 
b.  A user shall submit oral notice to the superintendent of an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable pretreatment standards within 24 hours from the time it becomes aware of the bypass. A written submission shall also be provided within five days of the time the user becomes aware of the bypass. The written submission shall contain a description of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent reoccurrence of the bypass. The superintendent may waive the written report on a case-by-case basis if the oral report has been received within 24 hours. 
(4)  a.  Bypass is prohibited, and the superintendent may take an enforcement action against a user for a bypass, unless: 
1.  Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury, or severe property damage; 
2.  There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not satisfied if adequate backup equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass which occurred during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance; and 
3.  The user submitted notices as required under subsection (c)(3) of this section. 
b.  The superintendent may approve an anticipated bypass, after considering its adverse effects, if the superintendent determines that it will meet the three conditions listed in subsection (4)a. of this subsection. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.180) 
Sec. 98-169. - Wastewater treatment and surcharge rates. 
    Wastewater treatment and surcharge rates shall be as recommended by the director of utilities and set by the city. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.190) 
Sec. 98-170. - Pretreatment program fees. 
    RMU may adopt reasonable fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating RMU's pretreatment program which may include: 
(1)  Fees for wastewater discharge permit applications including the cost of processing such applications; 
(2)  Fees for monitoring, inspection, and surveillance procedures including the cost of collection and analyzing a user's discharge, and reviewing monitoring reports submitted by users; 
(3)  Fees for reviewing and responding to accidental discharge procedures and construction; 
(4)  Fees for filing appeals; and 
(5)  Other fees as RMU may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained herein. These fees relate solely to the matters covered by this article and are separate from all other fees, fines, and penalties chargeable by RMU. 
(Code 1996, § 11.04.200(A)) 
Secs. 98-171-98-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRIC SERVICE 

Sec. 98-221. - General service regulations. 
(a)  Consumer information. Information desired from RMU concerning subject matters covered in this article may be obtained by telephone, by mail, or in person. 
(b)  Application for service. Any consumer desiring electric service shall make application at the RMU business office, using forms furnished by RMU. A transfer of service from one premise to another within the area served by RMU is not viewed as a discontinuance of service by RMU, the character of service remains the same, and the application should be for transfer of service. 
(c)  Types of service furnished. 
(1)  It is the customer's responsibility to secure information from RMU pertaining to the types of service available at a particular location. This information should be obtained prior to completion of design plans for the customer's electrical system. 
(2)  RMU furnishes 60 hertz (cycle) alternating current service. All types of service are not available in every locality. The type of service which will be provided at a particular location is ordinarily determined by one or more of the following conditions: 
a.  Type of service available at that location. 
b.  Type of load to be served. 
c.  Size of load to be served. 
See sections 98-242 through 98-248 for service limitations due to the customer's utilization equipment. 
(3)  The standard types of service and nominal secondary utilization voltages for customers are as follows: 
a.  Single-phase: 
1.  120/240 volt, three-wire. 
2.  120/208 volt, three-wire (from a three-phase, four-wire wye secondary system). 
b.  Three-phase: 
1.  120/208 volt, four-wire wye. 
2.  120/240 volt, four-wire delta. 
3.  277/480 volt, four-wire wye. (Ordinarily not available for loads having maximum demands below 50 kilowatts.) 
4.  240/480 volt, four-wire delta. (Ordinarily not available for loads having maximum demands below 50 kilowatts.) 
Service at these voltages will be provided from a grounded source except that service at 480 volts may be provided from an ungrounded source under certain conditions. Ungrounded 480-volt service will not be provided to any customer system not equipped with ground detectors. If present, a neutral conductor will be grounded by RMU. If, however, a customer requests that the neutral conductor not be so grounded in order that the customer can install impedance grounding facilities, RMU will provide an isolated neutral if RMU deems such neutral to be practical and if the customer provides, at customer expense, an acceptable ground fault detection and switching equipment installation. 
(4)  Voltages specified in this section are nominal and variations in voltages from nominal values are acceptable within limits. Voltage variations measured at the customer's service terminals shall normally not exceed for a period longer than one minute: 
a.  Five and eight-tenths percent above or below nominal voltage for service rendered for a lighting purpose. On RMU's 120V standard, the range of acceptable voltage is 127 volts maximum and 113 volts minimum. 
b.  Ten percent above or below nominal voltage for service rendered for a power purpose. 
(5)  For customers having maximum demands in excess of 300 kilowatts but not greater than 4,500 kilowatts, the standard secondary utilization voltage shall normally be three-phase, 480 volts or higher. For customers having maximum demands in excess of 4,500 kilowatts the standard utilization voltage shall normally be primary three-phase, 7,960/13,800 volts or higher. 
(6)  Customers having installations requiring service voltages other than those normally available as described in subsections (c)(3)a. and b.1.-6. of this section are requested to consult RMU for more complete information. Service may also be made available at primary three-phase voltages of 2,400/4,160 or 7,960/13,800 volts or higher where required by the customer's needs (i.e., for large loads, higher voltage utilization equipment, etc.). 
(d)  Primary voltages. 
(1)  The voltages of lines entering the customer's premises shall be determined by RMU on the basis of the size and characteristics of the customer's load and its relation to the facilities located in or projected for the area in which the customer is served. RMU may require the customer to accept a change in the voltage of some or all of the lines entering the premises when such a change is necessary either to prevent undue interference with service to other customers by reason of a change in the characteristics of the customer's load or to permit RMU to serve the customer more economically. In the event that a change is required for the latter reason, the following rules shall apply: 
a.  The estimated costs of the facilities required on the customer's property to enable the customer to receive service at the new voltage including, for example, the cost of foundations for a new electric service station and the cost of connecting a new electric service station to existing points of delivery, shall be apportioned between RMU and the customer as follows: 
1.  RMU shall bear the cost of facilities required solely to provide for existing load which is served from the lines to be replaced. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "existing load" means either: 
i.  The demand RMU has contracted to serve from the lines to be replaced; or 
ii.  If higher, or if no contract demand is applicable, the highest demand established by the customer on such lines within the three-year period prior to RMU's request that a change in voltage be accepted. 
2.  RMU shall bear a percentage of the cost of facilities to be used jointly for service to existing and proposed loads equal to the percentage of such loads represented by existing load; the customer shall bear the balance. 
3.  The customer shall bear the cost of facilities required solely to serve proposed additional load or with merely incidental usefulness for existing load. 
4.  If the customer has once become entitled to reimbursement by reason of an RMU-initiated change to a higher voltage, then the customer shall pay all facilities charges for a subsequent change to the higher voltage at a second or additional point of delivery. 
b.  The foregoing provisions with respect to the apportionment of costs shall not affect responsibility for the installation, ownership or maintenance of facilities. In the case of facilities to be installed, owned and maintained by the customer under RMU's established service policy, the portion of the estimated costs to be borne by RMU shall be paid by RMU to the customer. In the case of facilities to be installed, owned and maintained by RMU under its established service policy, the estimated costs to be apportioned shall be limited to those which the customer would ordinarily pay as optional facilities charges (see subsection (c) of this section) and the customer shall pay RMU the portion of such estimated costs which the customer is to bear under the rules set forth above. 
c.  All cost estimates shall be based upon the most economical service plan consistent with good engineering practice as determined by RMU. The customer may choose delivery points different from those selected by RMU or arrangements of his facilities different from those indicated by such service plan, but any additional costs resulting from the customer's choice shall be borne by the customer. 
d.  All cost computations shall include an appropriate allowance for any salvage available from facilities on the customer's property to be replaced. In lieu of reimbursing the customer for the cost of facilities which the customer requires to reestablish service at existing points of delivery, RMU may transfer to the customer, in serviceable condition, facilities on the customer's property previously used by RMU to provide such service. No payment will be made by RMU for land required for the location of an electric service station. 
(2)  If it is necessary to convert a customer's facilities to higher voltages to avoid interfering with service to other customers, the cost of such conversions shall be borne by RMU and the customer in accordance with the other provisions of this schedule and of the applicable rate schedule without regard to the provisions set forth in this subsection (d). 
(e)  Extensions. Where an extension of RMU's existing distribution system is necessary in order to furnish service, an advance deposit or optional facilities (see subsection (k) of this section) payment to cover the cost of the extension may be required in accordance with the provisions in RMU's schedules of rates. The customer is advised to make the necessary arrangements with RMU for such an extension before proceeding with the design of the installation on the premises. 
(f)  Temporary and seasonal service. 
(1)  When service of a temporary nature is required, RMU's estimated cost of furnishing, installing and removing facilities provided for such service shall be paid by the customer in accordance with the provisions in RMU's schedules of rates. 
(2)  When the customer requires use of electric service to be seasonal and requests RMU to disconnect or remove and reconnect or reinstall RMU facilities, the customer shall pay to RMU the estimated cost, including taxes, of any such work in accordance with RMU's rates. RMU may elect to use flat charges for work performed hereunder provided they do not exceed RMU's unit costs for such work. 
(3)  Temporary or seasonal service is not available for service to installations requiring standby service. 
(g)  Crossing adjacent property. If, in order to supply service to the customer, it is necessary to cross adjacent property with service conductors, then the customer shall be responsible for securing and maintaining the consent of the owner of the adjacent property. 
(h)  Permits, inspections, and approvals. The customer is responsible for obtaining all permits and approvals that are required by governmental authorities. Inspection of the customer's electric facilities for compliance with electrical codes is in the province of governmental authorities. In localities where governmental approval is required prior to providing service to the customer's installation, service will not be provided by RMU until such approval is obtained by the customer. Any costs or fees incurred in obtaining permits, inspections, or approvals shall be at the customer's expense. If a governmental authority requires RMU to disconnect electric service to a customer because of violation of such authority's electrical code, RMU will restore service only upon approval by the governmental authority to do so and upon payment by such customer of RMU's charges for such disconnection and restoration of service. 
(i)  Service requirements and examination. All wiring and other electrical equipment furnished by the customer, on the customer's premises, or connecting the premises with the company's service, should be suitable for such purposes, and shall be installed and maintained by the customer at all times in conformity with the requirements of the National Fire Protection Association and the properly constituted authorities and shall also be installed and maintained in conformance with the specifications and requirements contained in their book. Examination of the customer's equipment by RMU, however, shall not be assumed as evidence of compliance with all applicable codes. 
(j)  Tampering. RMU shall have the right to discontinue its electric service to the customer and furthermore to also remove its property from the customer's premises upon prior written notice any time RMU discovers evidence of tampering with any meter or the wiring leading from RMU's service connection to any meter, with the effect of reducing the registration of the customer's demand or energy use. The customer will be required to pay the amount of any RMU revenue loss attributable to such tampering in addition to other possible expenses and/or deposits as outlined in RMU's "terms and conditions" under the section entitled "Right of cut-off." 
(k)  Standard and optional facilities defined. 
(1)  The term "standard facilities" refers to an installation for a premises, in which RMU shall furnish facilities adequate to supply and meter at a single point of delivery electricity for a normal load equal to the maximum kilowatt demand (as defined in the applicable rate) of the customer at a power factor of not less than 95 percent lagging. 
(2)  The term "optional facilities," as used herein, applies to those facilities other than or in addition to those that have been determined by RMU to be a standard installation. Such facilities will be furnished at the customer's expense in accordance with the provisions in section 98-249. 
(l)  Alteration or change in size of installation. When alterations to or changes in the size of a customer's installation are contemplated, RMU should be notified as far in advance as possible so that arrangements can be made to facilitate any necessary changes in RMU's service and metering facilities. RMU will upgrade overhead facilities at no charge providing that additional load requirements warrant the upgraded facilities. Otherwise, additional charges may be required from the customer. 
(m)  Auxiliary or reserve service. When a customer has privately owned equipment for power production purposes on the customer's premises and also requires electric service from RMU, such electric service will be supplied by RMU in accordance with its schedule of rates. The customer shall consult RMU in advance regarding the conditions applicable for such service. 
(n)  Customer-owned facilities. When the customer furnishes, installs, owns, or maintains facilities used in conjunction with, or in lieu of, those provided by RMU for the connection and supply of electric service, such facilities shall be subject to RMU approval with regard to compatibility and protection of RMU facilities. 
(o)  Resale or redistribution of electricity. RMU's rate schedule prohibits the furnishing of electricity by a customer to a third person or persons, except under certain special conditions covered in detail in such schedule. It is therefore necessary that each individual occupant in a new of substantially remodeled and/or rewired premises be provided with a separate meter unless RMU determines that a special condition applies. 
(p)  Community transformer installation. A community transformer installation is generally a transformer installation (overhead or underground) not falling within the rule book designation of an electric service station, customer transformer station or a residential service station. Community transformer installations are available for service to more than one customer and include all installations on public property or on rights-of-way or easements acquired by RMU to serve the general public. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.010) 
Sec. 98-222. - Transformer installations on customer's property. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Where line voltage (2,400 volts or higher) is reduced on the customer's property to the service voltage required by the customer, the facilities necessary to accommodate the transformer or transformers will be either: 
a.  An electric service station, if furnished, installed, owned and maintained by RMU; or 
b.  A customer transformer station if furnished, installed, owned and maintained by the customer. Such facilities may be of the pole-mounted or ground type. 
(2)  If the customer is served at a secondary voltage from RMU facilities installed in public ways, easements or other RMU rights-of-way, such facilities are considered to be community facilities. 
If a customer, qualifying for a secondary voltage different from that available from the community facilities, requires such voltage or if the size or type of the customer's load precludes the use of such community facilities, RMU will serve the customer as standard from a transformer located on the customer's property. If the customer does not provide space on the property for an electric service station, RMU will serve the customer from community facilities by installing the transformer and related equipment in the distribution system, revising the system to accommodate the transformer installation, installing any secondary wires or cables in the system to supply the customer and providing the secondary service connection; however, the customer shall pay the amount by which the cost of such distribution facilities, revisions and services exceeds the cost of an electric service station on the customer's property. 
(b)  Electric service station. 
(1)  An electric service station is an installation on private property consisting of a transformation from a supply voltage to the customer's utilization voltage. The equipment is owned and maintained by RMU. An electric service station may include, in addition to the facilities to accommodate the transformer or transformers, facilities to accommodate primary metering equipment at the same location or within one span thereof furnished by RMU in accordance with sections 98-238 through 98-241. Where the customer's utilization requires electricity to be distributed on the premises at line voltage (2,400 volts or higher), the primary metering equipment facilities may then of themselves constitute the electric service station. 
(2)  RMU will install at its expense, where consistent with good engineering practice, a standard pole-mounted or ground-type electric service station for nonresidential customers. The installation of a standard electric service station may include modification of the transformer secondary terminals necessary to connect the customer's cables (except as noted in subsection (b)(3) of this section), secondary bus where RMU deems it necessary, secondary cable connectors, and attaching the connectors to the customer's cables and to the transformer or secondary bus. When electric service station facilities other than those considered standard are required, RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain such facilities in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(3)  If the number or size of secondary service connection cables and/or conduit required by the customer exceeds the connection capability of the compartmental transformer, the customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain a lockable junction cabinet approved by RMU and complying with all applicable codes at the electric service station. RMU shall furnish, install, own and maintain (subject to optional facilities) the necessary cables between the transformer and the junction cabinet. 
(4)  The customer shall provide an electric service station location acceptable to RMU and shall further provide, as required, installation of concrete foundations, fences, fireproof enclosures, ventilating, lighting, barriers, drainage facilities, and the like, all in accordance with applicable local codes and RMU's specifications. 
(c)  Customer transformer station. 
(1)  A customer transformer station comprises customer-owned facilities to accommodate transformers used to reduce the line voltage to the customer's service voltage. 
(2)  Nonresidential customers shall provide a customer transformer station if: 
a.  The customer elects to own the transformers necessary to reduce the line voltage; or 
b.  The transformers are connected to primary lines which extend beyond an electric service station at which there is primary metering. If the size of the load within a single building is such that primary metering is more practical than secondary metering, RMU may provide primary lines and electric service stations on the load side of the primary metering installation in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
Standard transformers and protective devices installed in conjunction with a customer transformer station provided by a nonresidential customer may be furnished and owned by RMU, in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities, but shall be installed or removed by the customer. 
(d)  Transportation of transformers. Where an electric service station, customer transformer station or residential service station is accessible to the company's truck, transformers will be transported to the station location. Where such a station is not easily accessible, any additional moving which may be necessary to place transformers in position for installation will be the customer's responsibility. The transformers will be installed by RMU in an electric service station or residential service station and by the customer in a customer transformer station. 
(e)  Facilities furnished by customer. All electric service facilities located on the customer's premises on the load side of an electric service station, except secondary metering equipment and standard transformers, shall generally be furnished, installed, owned and maintained by the customer. In those cases where the supply from an electric service station is 480 volts or less, the customer may, in preference to a cable and conduit installation, choose to install bus bars. If the customer so chooses, an insulated bus configuration furnished by the customer must terminate in a RMU approved manner. In such cases, RMU, in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities set forth in section 98-249, will furnish, install, own and maintain the facilities, including the copper bus bar, necessary to connect the customer's bus bars to RMU's transformers. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.020) 
Sec. 98-223. - Overhead primary service connections. 
(a)  Definition. An overhead primary service connection is that portion of the overhead supply conductors, with supports if required, between RMU's primary distribution system (2,400 volts and above) and an electric service station or a residential service station. 
(b)  Nonresidential customers. RMU will furnish an overhead primary service connection extending from RMU's overhead distribution system to the customer's electric service station. If required, up to two poles and three spans will be provided as standard facilities. If the primary service connection is longer than three spans, RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain the portion over two poles and three spans in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities pursuant to section 98-249. The length of spans shall not be in excess of that permitted by good engineering practice and RMU standards applicable to the voltage level of such connection. 
(c)  Residential customers. 
(1)  RMU will furnish an overhead primary service connection extending from RMU's overhead distribution system to the first point of attachment on private property, which point is normally on the customer's premises. The length of such connection shall not be in excess of that permitted by good engineering practice and RMU standards applicable to the voltage of such connection. 
(2)  If RMU's distribution system is across the street or highway from the customer's premises and an additional pole on the customer's side of the street or highway is required to assure proper clearance over the highway, CATV and telephone circuits, such pole will be provided by RMU as part of its system. If a pole which has been installed by the customer to provide proper clearance requires replacement, such pole will be replaced, owned and maintained by RMU at its expense, generally by installation on a street or highway right-of-way (subject to approval by the proper governmental authorities). 
(3)  In case a residential service station is located more than one span from RMU's overhead distribution system, the customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain the remainder of the overhead primary service connection including the first support on private property. 
(d)  Customer-owned primary service connection. When the customer installs the remainder of an overhead primary service connection, the customer should consult RMU for detailed information regarding its installation. Customer-owned facilities shall be installed in accordance with applicable local codes and RMU specifications and shall be suitable for connection to the portion of the service connection supplied by RMU. When practical, RMU will install, at its expense, suitable line protection equipment at the point at which the service connection is tapped to RMU's distribution system. 
(e)  Clearances. For service connections carrying a voltage of 2,400 volts or higher, RMU should be consulted for clearance requirements. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.030) 
Sec. 98-224. - Overhead secondary service connections. 
(a)  Definition. An overhead secondary service connection is that portion of the overhead supply conductors, with supports if required (see section 98-225(d)(2)), between RMU's secondary distribution system (480 volts and below), an electric service station, a customer transformer station, or a residential service station and the customer's service entrance equipment. 
(b)  All classes of customers. 
(1)  Where required, RMU will furnish a service drop to a customer's premises. A service drop is that portion of an overhead secondary service connection between a pole designated by RMU in the distribution system and a point of attachment on the customer's property. The length of a service drop will be determined by RMU on the basis of the conductor size required but in no case shall the length exceed 135 feet. 
(2)  If RMU's distribution system is across the street or highway from the customer's premises and an additional pole on the customer's side of the street or highway is required to assure proper clearances over the highway or CATV and telephone circuits, such pole will be provided by RMU as part of its system. If a pole which has been installed by the customer to provide for such proper clearances requires replacement, such pole will be replaced, owned, and maintained by RMU at its expense, generally by installation on a street or highway right-of-way. 
(3)  Where a service connection is not longer than the allowable length of a service drop and only one intermediate support is required for clearance or other reasons, such service connection shall be considered a service drop and the customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain the intermediate support. 
(4)  Where a service connection is either longer than the 135-foot standard allowable length of a service drop or requires more than one intermediate support, the service drop is the portion of the connection between RMU's distribution system and the first point of attachment on the customer's property. The remainder of the service connection, including the first support on private property, shall be furnished, installed, owned and maintained by the customer. 
(5)  If the service head is located within four feet of a RMU pole, no service attachment is required and RMU will attach the service drop wires directly to the service run wires. 
(6)  Where the supply to a premises is single-phase only, one single-phase service drop will be furnished as standard. 
(7)  A multiple-occupancy building normally shall be treated as a single premises with respect to the number of service drops which will be furnished, installed, owned and maintained by RMU; however, in certain instances RMU may elect to provide additional service drops to a building. Where two or more multiple-occupancy buildings are located on the same parcel of real estate, each building shall be considered as a single premises for the purposes of this subsection. 
(c)  Customer-owned secondary service connection. Where intermediate support is required for the service drop, or where the service connection must be extended beyond the service drop, the customer should consult with RMU for detailed information regarding the installation of such support or extension. A support to which a service drop is attached shall be located and installed by the customer as required by RMU and shall be of an approved size and type. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.032) 
Sec. 98-225. - Installation of secondary service connections. 
(a)  Service attachment defined. A service attachment is a device used to secure an overhead secondary service connection to a building or other structural support on the customer's premises. A service attachment may consist of house knobs, fork bolts, or other device depending on RMU's requirements. 
(b)  Location. 
(1)  The service attachment shall be located at a point designated by RMU and shall be sufficiently high above the ground to maintain the clearance requirements shown in subsection (d)(2) of this section, but in no case shall the service attachment on a building be less than ten feet or more than 30 feet above the ground at graded level. 
(2)  Under no circumstances shall a service attachment be located on a parapet or a chimney. 
(c)  Installation standards. 
(1)  Where service entrance equipment capacity does not exceed 400 amperes single-phase or 200 amperes three-phase, RMU will furnish without charge its standard service attachment and such attachment shall be installed by the customer. Where the customer desires or requires a service attachment other than that furnished by RMU, the attachment shall be of a type approved by RMU and shall be furnished and installed by the customer in accordance with RMU's instructions. 
(2)  Where the service entrance equipment capacity is larger than 400 amperes single-phase or 200 amperes three-phase, the customer shall furnish and install, in accordance with RMU specifications, either a steel anchorage plate and bolts or, if the building is of insufficient height, other acceptable anchorage. RMU will furnish and install on such an installation, devices necessary to secure the service connection to the anchorage. 
(3)  Where finishing is contemplated on the inside of the wall on which the service attachment is mounted, the washers or plates and the nuts or bolt heads which secure the attachment should be countersunk into the wall or studding and any protruding bolt ends cut off flush with the nuts. If countersinking is impractical, the metal parts on the inside of the wall should be insulated. 
(d)  Clearances. 
(1)  In order that the work to be done by RMU and by the customer may be properly coordinated and that proper clearances will be maintained, the customer shall obtain information from RMU as to the designated pole and the height on such pole where the service drop will be attached. Attachments and supports for service connections of 480 volts or less shall be installed to maintain, after provisions for normal sag, applicable clearance requirements set forth in the National Electrical Safety Code, as amended, and in governmental and local codes. 
(2)  The following is a tabulation of representative clearance requirements for service connections of 480 volts or less that are frequently encountered. This tabulation is intended as a guide. To obtain a complete tabulation of clearances it is suggested that reference be made to the National Electrical Safety Code as well as consulting with governmental and local authorities and RMU regarding clearance requirements. Each installation shall be reviewed in detail by the customer to ensure that it is in accordance with the applicable code. In the event that the customer installs or modifies any equipment or structure such that the electrical clearances for RMU facilities are reduced to the point of noncompliance with applicable codes, it will be the customer's responsibility to notify RMU prior to such action and arrange for appropriate modifications or relocation of RMU facilities at the customer's expense: 
Location Clearance Requirements 
(Conductor at Maximum Rated Temperature and No Wind) Over railroad tracks: For open supply conductors of 480 volts or less 24'6" For service drop cables of 480 volts or less 24'0" Over spaces and ways subject to pedestrians only (See note 1): For open supply conductors of 480 volts or less 12'6" For service drop cables of 480 volts or less 12'0" Over roads, streets, alleys, public driveways or over commercial, industrial, farm and residential private property driveways (See notes 2 and 3): For open supply conductors of 480 volts or less 16'6" For service drop cables of 480 volts or less 16'0" Above or below balconies and roofs accessible to pedestrians (See note 4): For open supply conductors of 480 volts or less 11'6" For service drop cables of 480 volts or less 11'0" Above or below roofs not accessible to pedestrians (See note 4): For open supply conductors of 480 volts or less 10'6" For service drop cables or 480 volts or less 3'6" Horizontal clearance from windows, porches, balconies, fire escapes, signs or any part of a building normally accessible to pedestrians (See note 4) including access for maintenance: For open supply conductors of 480 volts or less 5'6" For service drop cables of 480 volts or less 5'0" Horizontal clearance from communication or signal wires at the building 12" Conductors over a swimming pool or tank containing flammable materials Not allowed

A.  For insulated cabled or open wire (only using insulated conductors) service limited to 300 volts or less (phase to ground): Service drop and drip loop, 10'6". 
B.  For insulated cabled service only limited to 150 volts or less (phase to ground): Service drop and drip loop, 10'0". 
2.  For clearances over state rights-of-way see requirements outlined by the state department of transportation in its Illinois Accommodation of Utilities Plan.

Service drop: 12'6". 
Drip loop: 10'6".

Service drop: 12'0". 
Drip loop: 10'0". 
4.  A roof, balcony, or area is considered accessible to pedestrians if the means of access is through a doorway, ramp, stairway or permanently mounted ladder.

(3)  In order that work done by RMU and the customer is properly coordinated and that proper clearances are maintained, the customer shall consult RMU about the location of the RMU pole to which the service drop will be fastened and the height at which the service attachment must be placed on the building to ensure the clearances shown in subsection (d)(2) of this section. 
(4)  For service connections carrying a voltage in excess of 480 volts, RMU should be consulted for clearance requirements. 
(5)  In case a building is too low to provide the minimum clearances, a riser or roof bracket shall be installed by the customer in accordance with RMU's specifications. 
(6)  If RMU's pole from which service is to be taken is so close to a building that it is impractical to install a service drop in the usual manner, the customer shall install the service head adjacent to the pole at a point designated by RMU and RMU will make the connection. In this case no service attachment will be required. 
(7)  When a one-story building is located on an alley property line, and when the service drop from the pole to the building, if carried to the alley side of the building, would not provide sufficient clearance, the customer should consult RMU regarding the proper location for the service attachment. 
(8)  The service head and attachment shall be located so that: 
a.  The unenclosed wires will adequately clear downspouts, gutters and other building appurtenances; 
b.  The wires will be out of reach from windows, porches, or any other part of a building ordinarily accessible to the occupants or the public (see subsection (d)(2) of this section); and 
c.  The possibility of ice formation on the unenclosed wires is minimized. 
(e)  Connection of service. RMU will in all cases make the final connection of the customer's wiring facilities to RMU's overhead service drop; except that, if the customer provides a recessed head, RMU will furnish and attach lugs to the service drop conductors and the customer will attach the lugs to the bus inside the building. 
(f)  Relocation of service connection. 
(1)  If the customer requires the relocation of an overhead service connection, RMU will relocate its service connection and make any necessary changes in its facilities at the customer's expense. 
(2)  If, because of public improvement such as street widening, grading, excavating sidewalk spaces, or for other reasons beyond the customer's and RMU's control, RMU must move facilities with which it serves the customer, RMU as a condition of continued service may require that a new service connection, either primary or secondary, be established under the same terms as an original service connection from the standpoint of RMU and customer expense and installation. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.034) 
Sec. 98-226. - Underground service connections. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  RMU shall designate the point on RMU's distribution system or electric service station where the service connection will be attached. It is the customer's responsibility to furnish, install, own, and maintain underground service connections and underground residential services. 
(2)  For underground service connections to certain customers see sections 98-250 through 98-254. 
(b)  Repair or replacement of residential cable service connections. It is the customer's responsibility to repair and/or replace cable for residential service connections. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.040) 
Sec. 98-227. - Underground primary service connection defined. 
    An underground primary service connection consists of the underground supply conductors or cables, terminals, ducts, etc., between RMU's primary distribution system (2,400 volts and above) and an electric service station. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.041) 
Sec. 98-228. - Installation of underground primary service connections. 
    Before work is started by the customer on the installation of any portion of an underground primary service connection, a plan showing the proposed installation shall be submitted to RMU for its approval as related to RMU requirements. Such installation shall be made in accordance with the approved plan and be subject to examination to the extent deemed necessary by RMU. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.042) 
Sec. 98-229. - Underground primary service connections to primary distribution systems. 
(a)  Nonresidential customers. 
(1)  RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain as standard an underground primary service connection from RMU's underground distribution system to the property line and, subject to the conditions of subsection (b) of this section, an extension on private property at a cost not in excess of the cost of a standard two-pole, three-span service connection from the overhead system to an electric service station. Additional primary service connection facilities will be furnished in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(2)  Primary service connections on private property may be installed either in duct or, if the installation is practicable, by direct burial. If duct is used, the customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain the duct in accordance with the provisions of section 98-232(a). If direct burial cable is used, RMU will trench and backfill in addition to providing the cable at a cost not in excess of the cost of a standard two-pole, three-span service connection from the overhead system. Additional facilities will be furnished under optional facilities. Installation of direct burial cable is subject to the provisions of section 98-250(a)(2)-(6), (10) and (11). 
(b)  Residential customers. If the owner of a residence or apartment building with less than four units desires direct burial cable for an underground primary service connection from RMU's underground distribution system and if such an installation is practical, then, subject to the provisions of section 98-250(a)(2)-(6), (10) and (11), RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain such service connection at RMU's standard charge (see sections 98-253 and 98-254). 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.043) 
Sec. 98-230. - Underground primary service connections to overhead distribution centers. 
(a)  Nonresidential customers. 
(1)  If a nonresidential customer furnishes, installs, owns and maintains acceptable duct in accordance with provisions of section 98-232 from a point on the property line designated by RMU to an electric service station, RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain all other primary service connection facilities in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities (see section 98-223(b)). 
(2)  If the customer desires direct burial cable for the portion of the primary service connection on the customer's property and if such an installation is practical, then, subject to the provisions of section 98-250(a)(2)-(6), (10) and (11), RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain such cable and will trench and back fill in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities (see section 98-232). 
(b)  Residential customers. If the owner of a residence or an apartment building with less than four units desires direct burial cable for an underground primary service connection from RMU's overhead distribution system and if such service connection is practical, then, subject to the provisions of section 98-250(a)(2)-(6), (10) and (11), RMU will furnish, install, own and maintain such service connection at RMU's standard charge (see sections 98-253 and 98-254). 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.044) 
Sec. 98-231. - Underground secondary service connection defined. 
    An underground secondary service connection consists of the underground supply conductors or cables, including ducts where necessary, from either RMU's secondary distribution system (480 volts and below), or an electric service station, to an outdoor meter connection device, a junction cabinet, indoor meter connection device, instrument transformer cabinet, or disconnecting means. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.045) 
Sec. 98-232. - Underground secondary service connection to underground distribution system. 
    Secondary connections to underground distribution systems of nonresidential customers are the responsibility of the customer to furnish, install, own and maintain. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.046) 
Sec. 98-233. - Underground secondary service connections to overhead distribution systems. 
    The following shall apply to residential and nonresidential customers: 
(1)  If the customer wishes to do so and it is practical for a customer to take underground secondary service from RMU's overhead distribution system or an electric service station, the customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain all of the service connection located beyond the pole, service pedestal, or the electric service station. 
(2)  Where one or two customers take underground secondary service from the same RMU distribution pole, unless directed by RMU to follow the specifications of subsection (3) of this section, the customer shall furnish and install cable and duct extending from the customer's service entrance equipment to such pole and furnish sufficient additional cable to extend up the pole for connection to RMU's line. If the customer installs direct burial cable, the customer shall terminate the trench at the pole. If the customer installs cable in duct on the customer's property, such duct shall terminate with a bend at the base of the pole. The installation must meet RMU requirements and shall be subject to RMU approval and local codes. In either case, the balance of the installation to complete the connection to RMU's line will be made by RMU at its expense and it will own and maintain such portion of the installation except for the cable and the duct. In case the customer takes service from RMU's distribution system and municipal requirements do not permit him to install any necessary duct under public streets or alleys or on poles in public streets or alleys, RMU, in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities, will shall furnish, install, own and maintain the duct from the pole to the nearest point at the property line adjacent to such pole.
