(3)  Where more than two customers take underground secondary service from a single RMU distribution pole, or in case of one or two customers where RMU deems it necessary, each customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain all materials from the customer's service entrance equipment to a service pedestal. The customer's trench shall terminate at the pedestal and an additional eight feet of cable shall be left for connection to the pedestal. RMU will complete the trenching, install, own and maintain all necessary material from the pole to and including the pedestal and will connect the customer's cable to the pedestal. 
(4)  Where the connection of underground secondary service cable to an overhead line is made on a customer-owned pole or an electric service station, the service connection on and beyond the customer-owned pole or electric service station shall be furnished, installed, owned and maintained by the customer. Where RMU's service drop is attached to a customer-owned pole, the portion of the cable installed on the pole shall be installed in duct from and including a bend at the base of the pole to a point above the ground level to be determined by RMU. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.047) 
Sec. 98-234. - Installation of underground secondary service connections. 
(a)  Generally. That portion of the underground secondary service connection installed by a customer shall be at the location and grade designated by RMU for connection to its underground or overhead system or electric service station. When such connection is to be made, a plan showing the customer's proposed installation shall be submitted to RMU for approval as to its requirements before construction is started. Such an installation shall be made in accordance with the approved plan and RMU's requirements. The installation shall be subject to inspection by RMU to the extent deemed necessary. 
(b)  Secondary cable installation. 
(1)  Cable shall be installed in acceptable duct, or, if of a suitable type and in an acceptable location, may be buried directly in the ground. 
(2)  The minimum depth for installing cable in the ground shall be 24 inches. The horizontal separation between the cable and gas, water, and sewer pipes should be a minimum of 30 inches. 
(3)  Where cable is buried in the ground under public or private drives, roadways, streets, alleys, etc., protection from mechanical damage shall be provided by installing the cable in such areas in a duct suitable for this purpose. 
(4)  For three-phase service connections installed in duct at least one conductor, or an equal number of conductors, for each phase and the neutral conductor shall be in each duct. For single-phase service connections installed in duct at least one conductor, or an equal number of conductors, for each ungrounded side of the circuit and one neutral conductor shall be in each duct. If more than one duct is used, the conductor sizes should be chosen so that the ratios of the currents in each phase are the same in each duct. 
(c)  Duct installation. 
(1)  The underground duct installation for secondary utilization voltages shall consist of duct suitable for this purpose and shall be installed in as straight a line as possible and on an even grade without dips or bumps. Where possible the slope of the duct shall be toward the service pole or underground distribution line. 
(2)  Service ducts installed by the customer from the end of an existing or proposed RMU's duct run, shall be of the same size and formation and at least the same number as RMU's ducts. 
(3)  Where cable not in duct is to enter a building, the section of cable extending through the wall shall be enclosed in suitable and properly sized conduit which extends out from the building to a point beyond where the earth has been disturbed by excavating for the building. 
(4)  Where cable installed in metallic duct is to enter a building wall, such duct may be extended through the building wall. 
(5)  Where the underground secondary service connection enters the building, the entrance shall be properly sealed to prevent water seepage. The customer shall seal the intervening space between the wall and the duct. The customer shall seal the space between the duct wall and the cable in each occupied duct and the openings in any spare duct. The customer shall be responsible for maintenance of these seals. 
(6)  The portion of service ducts containing RMU-owned cables, inside a building, shall not be installed in any location where they would be subjected to excessive heat, such as near boilers, steam mains, etc. 
(7)  Service duct containing RMU-owned cables, extending more than five feet within a building shall be entirely covered with a suitable fireproofing material such at two inches of concrete. 
(d)  Relocation of underground service connections (all classes of customers). 
(1)  If the customer requires the relocation of an underground service connection for his convenience, because of construction, or to avoid overbuilding or otherwise obstructing access to the service connection, the customer will, at the customer's expense, relocate the service connection and make any necessary changes in other equipment previously furnished and installed at the customer's expense. 
(2)  If, because of public improvement such as street widening, grading, excavating sidewalk spaces, or for other reasons beyond the customer's and RMU's control, RMU must move facilities with which it serves the customer, RMU, as a condition of continued service, may require that a new service connection, either primary or secondary, be established under the same terms as an original service connection from the standpoint of RMU and customer expense and installation. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.048) 
Sec. 98-235. - Service entrance equipment. 
(a)  Definition; components. 
(1)  The service entrance equipment, in the case of an overhead secondary service connection, will include some or all of the following: a service head, a service run, a meter connection device, an instrument transformer cabinet, service entrance, disconnecting means, and an approved ground connection. 
(2)  The service entrance equipment, in the case of an underground secondary service connection, will include some or all of the following: a junction cabinet, a meter connection device, an instrument transformer cabinet, service entrance, disconnecting means, and an approved ground connection. 
(3)  The service entrance equipment, in the case where the customer desires the installation of a meter on a pole and a secondary service supply from a single point of delivery to one or more buildings, may consist of the equipment listed in either subsection (a)(1) or (2) of this section. RMU should be consulted regarding the requirements for such equipment. 
(4)  A service head is a weather-tight fitting attached to the free end of a service run and is used to prevent water from entering the service run. 
(5)  A service run consists of conduit or tubing (rigid metal, intermediate metal, electrical metallic, rigid non-metallic approved for this purpose) with enclosed conductors, or an approved service entrance cable, installed between the service head and either the outdoor meter connection device or, in the case of indoor metering, the point where the service entrance equipment enters the building. 
(6)  A meter connection device is a device to which a meter is attached and may consist of a meter socket for a single or three-phase self-contained meter, or a combination meter socket and test switch for an instrument transformer meter installation. 
(7)  A junction box or cabinet is a metal enclosure suitable for the connection of the customer's cables to RMU's cables. 
(8)  An instrument transformer cabinet consists of a metal enclosure containing the assembly and necessary supports for the installation of the instrument transformers, cables and color-coded conductors. 
(9)  A service entrance consists of either rigid metallic or intermediate metal conduit, electric metallic tubing or rigid non-metallic conduit approved for this purpose with enclosed conductors or approved service entrance cable. If the service entrance includes rigid nonmetallic conduit, the continuity of the equipment ground shall be maintained with a metallic (bonding) conductor. The service entrance, in the case of either indoor or outdoor metering, connects the metering equipment and the disconnecting means installed in conjunction with and, in the case of indoor metering, includes either: 
a.  The continuation of the service run from the point where the service entrance equipment enters the building to either the metering equipment or the disconnecting means; 
b.  In the case where a junction cabinet is installed by RMU, the conductors and conduit connecting the junction cabinet to either the metering equipment or the disconnecting means; or 
c.  In the case where a recessed head is installed, the connectors, bus conductors and the bus enclosure, where required, connecting the terminals of the service connection to the metering equipment or the disconnecting means. 
(10)  A disconnecting means is a device or devices used to disconnect all conductors, except the grounded neutral, from the source of supply. For further information see subsections (c)(1)-(4) of this section. 
(11)  A ground connection consists of a conductor (metallic protection if any) and clamps which are used to connect all metallic enclosures of an electrical installation and the neutral conductor to two grounding electrodes minimum, installed in conformance with the applicable electrical code (local code or National Electrical Code). For further information see section 98-236(a) and (b). 
(b)  Service entrance equipment requirements. 
(1)  The service run shall be installed entirely on the outside of the building to be served. Conductors in conduit or duct placed under at least two inches of concrete beneath a building, or buried in two inches of brick masonry or in concrete within a wall, shall be considered outside the building. Where the service entrance passes through the wall of the building it shall pass through the wall as close as practical to the point at which it is to be terminated. 
(2)  The customer shall furnish, install, own and maintain all service entrance equipment other than the metering equipment. Meter connection devices, including wiring or bus connections within such devices, shall be furnished and installed by the customer. RMU will, at its expense, when requested by the customer, make certain necessary repairs of the parts enclosed in the meter connection device if parts are available. RMU will not, however, replace the cabinet or enclosure. 
(3)  The conductors and conduit of the service entrance equipment shall be continuous (i.e., conductors not spliced; the conduit system electrically and mechanically continuous) on the line side of the meter or meters, except that: 
a.  The conductors may be tapped in approved fittings for the connection of individual meter connection terminals to the service conductors supplying a multiple-occupancy building; and 
b.  Approved self-locking fittings may be substituted for conduit bends. 
(4)  The conductor of service run and service entrance shall meet or exceed the amperage rating of the disconnecting device as defined by local code or the National Electrical Code. Wire size will be as follows: 
Service Amperage Copper Wire Aluminum Wire 60 #6 #6 100 #4 #2 150 #1 #2/0 200 2/0 4/0 400 400 mcm 600 mcm  
(5)  Weathertight fittings shall be used in connecting a service run or service entrance to an outdoor meter connection device. 
(6)  All service runs shall be equipped with service heads. 
(7)  Metered and unmetered conductors shall not be installed in the same conduit, raceway, or switchboard section unless separated by an approved barrier or raceway (conduit). 
(8)  The grounded neutral conductor of either a single-phase or three-phase, four-wire installation; the ground return conductor of a three-phase, four-wire, delta installation, and in the case of a three-phase, four-wire, delta installation, the conductor for the phase having the highest voltage to ground shall be identified in such a manner that they are readily distinguishable. 
(c)  Disconnecting means. 
(1)  The customer's service entrance equipment shall include a readily accessible means of disconnection from RMU's distribution system. 
(2)  A service disconnecting means shall be installed on the load side of each meter. 
(3)  All conductors on the line side of the metering equipment and between the termination of the service entrance conduit and the customer's bus bars shall be readily accessible for examination. 
(4)  Each service disconnecting means rated at 600 amperes or more shall have ground fault protection furnished, installed and maintained by the customer. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.050) 
Sec. 98-236. - Grounding. 
(a)  All metallic components and the neutral conductor or ground return conductor of the service entrance equipment shall be permanently grounded. 
(b)  One end of a ground connection (the grounding conductor and its metallic protection, if any) shall be connected by means of a permanently effective ground clamp to a minimum of two metallic grounding electrodes in accordance with the requirements of the applicable local code or the National Electrical Code. No grounding connection to a water system will be allowed. 
(c)  The other end of a ground connection shall be connected at the disconnecting means, or at a pole-mounted outdoor meter connection device where a disconnecting means is not installed. 
(1)  If connected at the disconnecting means: 
a.  The grounding conductors shall be connected to the ground lug (attached to the neutral or ground phase bus) and the grounding screw of the disconnecting means; and 
b.  The metallic protection of the grounding conductor, if any, shall be connected to the enclosure for such disconnecting means. 
(2)  If connected to an outdoor meter connection device, the grounding conductor shall be connected to the ground stud of such device and the metallic protection, if any, to the enclosure of such device. 
(d)  The neutral or ground return conductor of the service entrance equipment conductors shall be connected to the neutral bus or terminal of the disconnecting means, and to the ground stud or terminal of the meter connection device. 
(e)  Ground connections to a water piping system are prohibited. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.052) 
Sec. 98-237. - Metering. 
(a)  Metering equipment which will be provided by RMU consists of one or more of the following items as are required for the particular installation: watt-hour meters, demand registers, recording demand devices, associated relays and devices and instrument transformers. The equipment supplied by RMU for a specific installation will be dependent upon the billing requirements of the applicable rate and RMU's standard practices. RMU will only allow metering equipment to be installed on its poles or equipment in limited circumstances and then only with advance approval of RMU. 
(b)  Tampering with a RMU meter, breaking of meter seals, and/or installing conductors to carry unmetered current is prohibited by law and may result in criminal prosecution. Meters or service connections, etc. shall not be disconnected, removed or relocated without RMU's authorization. Tampering with any meter, the associated wiring or related facilities to reduce a customer's metered usage may result in disconnection of service and/or require a service deposit. In addition, the customer will be billed for the estimated revenue loss attributable to the said tampering plus all related expenses incurred in replacing and/or repairing facilities. 
(c)  If the metering equipment is compatible, RMU may provide meter contacts at customer request and expense for KYZ pulses, end of interval pulses, and demand thresholds. 
(d)  Load profiles may be provided by RMU at customer expense if metering equipment permits this option. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.060) 
Sec. 98-238. - Types of metering. 
(a)  Self-contained installations. 
(1)  Self-contained metering equipment shall be installed for all new or revised installations if the supply voltage of the service to be metered is 240 volts or less and the disconnecting means has a rating equal to or less than: 
a.  200 amperes, three-phase. 
b.  350 amperes, extended service, single-phase for nonresidential customers with approved extended meter socket. 
c.  350 amperes, extended service, single-phase for residential customers with approved extended meter socket. 
The provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall apply to subsection (1)b. of this section when the disconnecting means is over 300 amperes and is U.L. listed for continuous duty of 100 percent of its rating. 
(2)  Any existing self-contained bottom-connected meter installation which fails or causes trouble for the customer shall be replaced by the customer with a RMU approved self-contained socket-type meter installation. 
(b)  Instrument transformer installations. 
(1)  A current transformer metering installation (a metering installation which utilizes current transformers) shall be installed for all new installations or installations revised to provide for additional load if the supply voltage of the service to be metered is 480 volts or less and the disconnecting means has a rating in excess of: 
a.  200 amperes, three-phase. 
b.  350 amperes, single-phase for nonresidential customers. 
c.  350 amperes, single-phase for residential customers. 
d.  300 amperes, single-phase for all customers when the disconnecting means is U.L. listed for continuous duty of 100 percent of its rating. 
(2)  Any existing self-contained metering installation which exceeds the current rating of the equipment must be upgraded to the appropriate size together with the service connection to be metered at the customer's expense. 
(3)  Where the supply voltage is higher than 240 volts, current and potential transformers shall be installed for all new or revised metering installations. 
(4)  Metered and unmetered conductors shall not be installed in the same conduit, raceway or switchboard section unless separated by an approved barrier or raceway. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.062) 
Sec. 98-239. - Metering sequence. 
(a)  Definition. A meter-switch-fuse sequence is an installation where the metering equipment is connected to the supply side of the disconnecting means installed in conjunction with the meter. A switch-fuse-meter sequence is an installation where the metering equipment is connected on the load side of the disconnecting means installed in conjunction with the meter. 
(b)  Single-phase and three-phase type. 
(1)  A meter-switch-fuse sequence shall be followed for all single or multi-unit self-contained or instrument transformer metering installations. 
(2)  Where variances or exceptions to the rules for metering sequence are requested, RMU's approval must be obtained prior to installation. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.064) 
Sec. 98-240. - Location of metering equipment. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  The customer shall provide a suitable place for the metering equipment which shall be readily accessible to employees of RMU for the reading, testing, inspecting or exchanging of such equipment. The location of the equipment shall not conflict with state or local governmental code requirements. The customer shall consult RMU regarding the proper location of the equipment. 
(2)  For all new and revised single-phase and three-phase installations requiring the use of a self-contained meter, the metering equipment shall be installed outside of the building. 
(3)  For all new and revised single-phase and three-phase installations requiring the use of instrument transformers, the metering equipment shall be located as specified below: 
a.  When the utilization voltage is 480 volts or less and the disconnecting means is rated at 200 through 1,200 amperes, the metering equipment, where practical, shall be installed outside of the building. The metering equipment includes the meters, the associated current transformers and the demand metering equipment. 
b.  For all other installations requiring the use of instrument transformers, the metering equipment must be located outside the building unless an indoor installation of any or all of the components is specifically designated by RMU. 
(4)  When modernizing or upgrading work is performed on existing indoor metering installations, it is required, where practical, that all meters, both single-phase and three-phase, be relocated outdoors. 
(5)  Metering equipment shall not, for example, be installed in any of the following locations: 
a.  Attics; 
b.  Basements projecting under sidewalks; 
c.  Bathrooms; 
d.  Chemical rooms; 
e.  Clothes closets; 
f.  Coal bins; 
g.  Crawl spaces and stairways; 
h.  Dog yards or runs; 
i.  Fenced yards with locked gates; 
j.  Incinerator rooms; 
k.  Kitchens; 
l.  Lavatories; 
m.  Manholes; 
n.  Shower and locker rooms; or 
o.  Storerooms. 
(6)  Metering equipment shall not, for example, be installed behind, over, under, or adjacent to: 
a.  Boilers; 
b.  Chemical tanks; 
c.  Doors; 
d.  Exposed machinery; 
e.  Fire escapes; 
f.  Furnaces; 
g.  Hatches; 
h.  Heaters; 
i.  Laundry tubs; 
j.  Natural gas meter (see note); 
k.  Radiators; 
l.  Sinks; 
m.  Steam pipes; 
n.  Stoves; 
o.  Tanks; 
p.  Tracks for overhead doors; or 
q.  Windows. 
Note: Metering equipment must maintain a three-foot minimum clearance from a natural gas meter pursuant to subsection (a)(9) of this section. 
(7)  Metering equipment shall not be installed in locations where there is excessive heat, moisture, vibrations, fumes, a corrosive or explosive atmosphere or dust, or against downspouts, or in locations subject to flooding. 
(8)  Outdoors, metering equipment shall not protrude over a sidewalk, driveway, loading ramp, or be exposed to possible mechanical damage. 
(9)  Metering equipment shall not be installed within three feet of any gas meter, gas valve, or disconnected gas fitting. Metering equipment shall not be installed in areas with a corrosive or explosive atmosphere. 
(10)  Access to meter locations (meter rooms) shall be through public walkways, halls, etc., and not through locked or private rooms, tenant space, lavatories, limited access ways, etc. 
(11)  Metering equipment approved for installation indoors shall be located as near as practical to the point where the service entrance conductors enter the building and in accordance with local code requirements. When two or more metering equipment devices are installed within the building, the meter devices shall be grouped together in the same room and on the same wall. 
(12)  Where metering equipment is installed on balconies, access must be by stairs, not ship ladders. The customer must provide platform space in front of the metering equipment of at least three feet and be protected by a suitable railing. 
(13)  Where metering equipment is to be installed in a narrow passageway or in a narrow space such as in back of tanks, switchboards, or machines properly guarded, the minimum clear space in front of the metering equipment shall be three feet. 
(14)  Metering equipment placed behind uninsulated heating tanks, machines in motion, etc., shall be located at a distance from such equipment as specified by RMU. 
(15)  For large multiple-occupancy buildings requiring an indoor location for the metering equipment, the equipment may be grouped together and installed in an accessible location in the basement or on the first floor. High-rise buildings may find it more practicable to have the metering equipment located on each or every other floor in special meter rooms. Meters shall not be installed in individual tenant space. Where meter rooms are necessary, they shall be of sufficient size to allow ready access to the meter and its accessories for the purpose of reading, testing, and maintenance. Where meter rooms are locked, keys must be available to RMU personnel at all times. 
(b)  Recording demand register or totalizing meter. When a recording demand register or totalizing meter is required for a large commercial or industrial customer, the customer shall consult RMU as to the location of the metering equipment. 
(c)  Metering voltage over 600 volts. 
(1)  The rules herein stated will also apply to the location of watt-hour meters where the metering voltage exceeds 600 volts. The location of the instrument transformers will vary with the voltage and type of service. Specifications and prints shall be submitted to RMU for approval as related to RMU requirements before any equipment is purchased, installed or constructed. 
(2)  Where variances or exceptions to the rules for metering location are requested, RMU approval must be obtained prior to installation. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.066) 
Sec. 98-241. - Installation of meters. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Meter connection devices of a type approved by RMU (both indoor and outdoor) shall be furnished, installed and maintained by the customer. 
(2)  RMU has certain minimum and maximum mounting heights as well as minimum acceptable front and side clearances for meter installations. This information is available from RMU. 
(3)  When metering equipment is installed in a multiple-occupancy building (two or more occupants), each meter connection device shall be labeled, tagged, or stenciled by the customer to show the complete address and location of the area served. This includes the apartment, office, or store in the building for which the metering equipment is being installed. 
(4)  Conduit or wire connections to an instrument transformer meter connection device shall be made below the meter test switch using the knockouts provided. 
(5)  All metering facilities shall be installed in such a manner as to be plumb and to ensure permanent attachment to a rigid, vibration-free wall or structure. 
(b)  Self-contained meter connection devices. 
(1)  The customer shall provide and install a mounting board in accordance with RMU's specifications for all indoor installations of single or multiple-position meter connection devices where the condition of the wall precludes a plumb installation. 
(2)  In the case of multiple-position or grouped meter connection devices, conductors or bus from the source of supply shall be continuous to the last meter connection device and connected to the meter connection device terminals in accordance with RMU's requirements. 
(3)  Metered load conductors shall not pass through adjacent meter connection devices unless such conductors are properly barriered from the unmetered conductors and are an integral part of an approved prewired multiple-position meter socket assembly. 
(4)  Where meter connection devices are installed in locations not adjacent to the service entrance, the unmetered feeder conductors, to the extent practical, should be installed with a continuous run of conduit and cable without splice boxes or similar type fittings. 
(c)  Instrument transformers. 
(1)  An instrument transformer metering installation generally consists of instrument transformers, an instrument transformer cabinet containing color-coded conductors, a meter connection device with test switches and a watt-hour meter with an appropriate demand device. 
(2)  Except where instrument transformers are a part of an electric service station, they shall be installed by the customer. 
(3)  Unless outdoor type instrument transformers are provided the customer shall furnish, install and maintain a cabinet approved by RMU or under the conditions set forth in subsections (c)(4) and (5) of this section, a suitable enclosure for the instrument transformers. If the cabinet is to be installed outdoors, it shall be weatherproof. 
(4)  Upon specific approval by RMU, instrument transformers may be installed in a common cabinet with the disconnecting means provided that the portion of the cabinet containing the transformers is separated by means of an isolating barrier from the portion containing the disconnecting means, and provided further that the cabinet is constructed in accordance with RMU's requirements. In the case of such an installation the connection of the supply conductors to either the disconnecting means or the current transformer shall be accessible for inspection. The instrument transformer compartment shall contain only supply conductors and meter wiring. Specifications and prints shall be submitted to RMU for approval as related to RMU requirements before any equipment is purchased or constructed. 
(5)  Where the equipment and wiring requirements for an instrument transformer installation are not set forth in RMU's current published drawings and specifications, the customer shall furnish specifications and prints for RMU approval as related to RMU requirements of such installation before any equipment is purchased or constructed. This equipment shall be installed in accordance with RMU requirements. 
(d)  Color-coded wires. Except where the meter is mounted on the door of the instrument cabinet, with appropriate wiring connections, the customer shall provide a suitable conduit extending between the instrument transformer cabinet and the meter connection device. The customer shall install such conduit, exposed where practical, and the color-coded conductors (provided by RMU) which connect the instrument transformers to the meter test switch. RMU will make the final connections. Where the instrument transformers are to be installed on a RMU pole or structure, RMU will provide the conduit to be installed on the pole or structure and install the instrument transformers, the conduit, and conductors on the pole or structure. 
(e)  Instrument transformer meter connection devices and recording demand devices. 
(1)  The meter connection device shall be installed as close as practical to the instrument transformer cabinet. 
(2)  When recording demand equipment is required the customer shall consult RMU as to the location of the metering equipment. 
(f)  Compliance. RMU may refuse to connect service if, in its judgment, the customer's metering installation does not meet RMU's requirements herein stated. Even if service is connected, the customer is responsible for the adequacy, conformance to codes, safety and reliability of the equipment and facilities owned, installed and maintained by the customer. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.068) 
Sec. 98-242. - Equipment causing interference or requiring additional facilities. 
(a)  In order that RMU may avoid unnecessary delays in providing adequate and uniform service to its customers, it is recommended that the customer, prior to purchase, submit to RMU information regarding any equipment which is thought might cause interference with service to other customers or require additional facilities for its satisfactory operation. 
(b)  RMU reserves the right to examine and test any equipment connected to its lines and to require that such equipment be provided with nameplates showing the voltage, phase, full-load amperes, maximum current, maximum kilovolt-amperes, and such other information as may be necessary to determine the operating characteristics of the equipment. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.070) 
Sec. 98-243. - Single-phase service. 
(a)  In general all miscellaneous single-phase equipment in the 120 volt class may be operated as follows: Either a 120/208, 120/240, or higher supply voltage (depending on the service voltage in that area) should be used if the aggregate rating of such equipment exceeds two horsepower, two kilowatts, or two kilovolt-amperes. Such equipment shall be balanced on the phase conductors as closely as practicable. 
(b)  Any single-phase piece of equipment having a rated capacity in excess of two kilowatts or two kilovolt-amperes shall be operated at not less than 208 volts. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.072) 
Sec. 98-244. - Three-phase service. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Three-phase service may be provided for any single-phase load where, in RMU's judgment, the customer's total connected load is of a size that three-phase is desirable. Where three-phase service is supplied, all single-phase load shall be balanced on all phase conductors as closely as practical. 
(2)  Any motor with a rated capacity in excess of five horsepower shall normally be three-phase. Single-phase motors with a rated capacity in excess of five horsepower shall not be operated from RMU's system except in such locations where, in RMU's judgment, the available distribution line has sufficient capacity to permit such operation. 
(b)  Residential customers. 
(1)  Three-phase service will be provided for residential customers upon request irrespective of the amount of the connected load. If a three-phase secondary supply is not available adjacent to the customer's property, the necessary primary and secondary extensions will be furnished by RMU without charge if: 
a.  Three-phase service is required for the operation of a motor not smaller than ten horsepower or for motors with an aggregate of 20 horsepower; and 
b.  The three-phase motor load to be served does not include any motor with starting Kva exceeding that of a standard 30 horsepower squirrel-cage induction motor (150 Kva). 
(2)  For three-phase loads which do not meet these conditions, the necessary primary and/or secondary overhead extensions(s) will be installed in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. The cost of such optional facilities will include, where necessary for such service, the cost of extending any primary phase and/or secondary phase wires. The company may, at its option, provide a suitable phase converter in lieu of making a three-phase line extension. 
(c)  Nonresidential customers. 
(1)  Three-phase service will be provided: 
a.  Upon request: 
1.  Where the normal load includes three-phase equipment but also totals more than ten kilowatts (considering motor load as one kilowatt per horsepower and not including lighting, domestic ranges, water heaters, welders, or motors smaller than one-half horsepower); or 
2.  Where the normal load includes five horsepower or more of three-phase motors (not including any motors rated at less than one-half horsepower); or 
b.  Where required in RMU's judgment (see subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(2)  If a nonresidential customer requiring three-phase service does not qualify for three-phase service under subsection (c)(1) of this section, the additional RMU facilities necessary to furnish such service, including the necessary primary and secondary overhead line extension, will be installed by RMU in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(3)  When a nonresidential customer being supplied with three-phase service reduces the connected load below the conditions stated in subsections (c)(1)b. and (2) of this section, the supply of three-phase service will be continued provided the customer pays the necessary charges in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(4)  For a nonresidential customer who qualifies for three-phase service under subsections (c)(1)b. and (2) of this section, the necessary primary and/or secondary overhead line extensions will be furnished without charge if: 
a.  Three-phase service is required for the operation of a motor not smaller than ten horsepower or for motors with an aggregate of 20 horsepower; and 
b.  The three-phase motor load to be served does not include any motor with starting Kva exceeding that of a standard 30 horsepower squirrel-cage induction motor (150 Kva). 
(5)  For a nonresidential customer who qualifies for three-phase service under the provisions of subsections (c)(1)b. and (2) of this section, but does not meet the provisions of subsection (c)(4) of this section, the necessary primary and/or secondary overhead extension(s) will be installed by RMU in upon payment in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. The company may, at its option, provide a suitable phase converter in lieu of making a three-phase line extension. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.073) 
Sec. 98-245. - Starting currents. 
(a)  Motors having locked rotor currents which conform to industry standards (EEI-NEMA) are approved for use throughout RMU's system, as follows: 
Equipment (1) Type and Voltage of Equipment Maximum Starting Current (2) Conventional motorized equipment rated in horsepower 120 volts, single-phase 240 volts, single-phase 52.2 amperes 2 horsepower or less 62.6 amperes Over 2 horsepower, but not over 5 horsepower 62.6 amperes plus 20.9 amperes per horsepower over 2 horsepower 240 volts, three-phase: 2 horsepower or less 54.5 amperes Over 2 horsepower but not over 20 horsepower 54.5 amperes plus 15.3 amperes per horsepower over 2 horsepower Air conditioning or heat pump equipment rated in Btu per hour 120 volts, single-phase 52.2 amperes 240 volts, single-phase: 20,000 Btuh or less 62.2 amperes Not over 50,000 Btuh 3.1 amperes per 1,000 Btuh over 20,000 Btuh 240 volts, three-phase: 20,000 Btuh or less 54.5 amperes Over 20,000 Btuh but not over 50,000 Btuh 54.5 amperes plus 2.7 amperes per 1,000 Btuh over 20,000 Btuh Over 50,000 Btuh but not over 225,000 Btuh 136.4 amperes plus 1.1 amperes per 1000 Btuh over 50,000 Btuh  
Notes: 
(1)  The table applies to installations where there are not more than four starts per hour, with long periods of continuous operation under maximum load conditions. 
(2)  Starting current is the locked rotor current taken from the supply line with all power consuming components including a current reducing starter if used, connected in the starting position. Where the equipment contains motors arranged for sequence starting, the table applies to that combination of power consuming components which produces the highest starting current. The interval between successive steps shall not be less than one-half second. 
_____
(b)  RMU will, upon request, furnish information regarding permitted starting currents and other current fluctuations in cases not covered by subsection (a) of this section. The currents permitted will depend upon the frequency of operation, the size, and character of the customer's load, and the design of RMU's supply system in the area and, will generally be equivalent to the maximum current which, in RMU's opinion, can be supplied without causing: 
(1)  Undue interference with service to other customers; 
(2)  RMU to provide additional or different facilities, such as a larger transformer than that considered standard for the customer's load; or 
(3)  Damage to RMU facilities. 
(c)  Whenever a customer's starting current or other current fluctuation beyond permitted limits causes undue interference to other customers, the customer shall provide a starting device or a starting device and a motor of a type which will eliminate such interference. Where practical, RMU may furnish suitable facilities to eliminate the interference or damage to other customers or RMU's facilities in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.074) 
Sec. 98-246. - Interfering loads. 
(a)  Whenever a customer's utilization equipment, other than equipment acceptable under section 98-245(a) and (b), has characteristics which cause undue interference to other customers, the customer shall make changes in such equipment or provide and maintain, at the customer's expense, the necessary additional equipment to prevent or eliminate such interference; however, where practical, RMU may furnish, in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities, the necessary facilities to prevent or eliminate such interference. 
(b)  When a customer desires additional RMU facilities (such as transformers) to minimize voltage fluctuations on the customer's own electrical circuits or to provide satisfactory operation of the customer's equipment such as, but not limited to, welders, induction heating equipment, X-ray machines or computer and data processing equipment, such facilities, where practical, may be furnished by RMU in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(c)  High-frequency equipment such as, but not limited to, electronic heating equipment, spark discharge devices, radio transmitting equipment, etc., shall be designed and operated so as not to create higher frequencies or other disturbances on RMU's 60 hertz (cycle) electrical system which might interfere with the proper operation of communication or remote control systems, computers, electronic production equipment, radios, or other utilization equipment of RMU's other customers. 
(d)  Two or more pieces of utilization equipment, such as motors, welders, etc., controlled simultaneously through one control device, shall be considered as a single unit for the purpose of this section's requirements. 
(e)  Undervoltage release starting equipment is required on all motors seven and one-half horsepower and larger. The undervoltage release shall be of a type that returns the starting device to the off position when the electric supply is interrupted. Under certain conditions, time delay under-voltage release starting equipment will be permitted. 
(f)  Manually operated reduced voltage starting devices shall be so constructed that they cannot be placed in the running position before passing through the starting position. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.075) 
Sec. 98-247. - Power factor. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Whenever the customer's utilization equipment has characteristics that produce low power factor, RMU reserves the right to require the customer to correct the low power factor at the time of the customer's maximum demand to a value not less than 95 percent lagging as measured at the point of metering. 
(2)  When RMU requires the customer to correct the low power factor of the customer's installation, either: 
a.  The customer shall, at the customer's expense, furnish, install, and maintain the necessary corrective equipment to correct the power factor to comply with RMU's minimum requirements; or 
b.  RMU will furnish the necessary facilities in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(b)  Installation of capacitors. When a customer installs capacitors on the secondary side of RMU's transformers to improve the power factor of the customer's installation, the customer shall furnish, at the request of RMU, in order to avoid abnormal voltages or damage to transformer, a means of automatically disconnecting any or all of the capacitors when the equipment causing the low power factor is not operating. Where it is not practical for the customer to comply with RMU's request to install the secondary capacitors with an automatic disconnecting means, RMU will shall furnish, in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities, any necessary additional transformer capacity and/or primary capacitors with such automatic disconnecting means as may be required. However, if the customer owns the primary service connection, the customer may install such capacitor installations on such connection and RMU will furnish any necessary additional transformer capacity under the conditions described above. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.076) 
Sec. 98-248. - Miscellaneous equipment. 
(a)  Welders. Transformer type welders shall not be operated from a service voltage of less than 208 volts. 
(b)  Flashing signs. All flashing signs having more than one circuit shall be balanced on the phase conductors as closely as practical throughout each portion of the flashing cycle. 
(c)  Furnaces and ovens. Resistance furnaces or ovens rated 30 kilovolt-amperes or larger shall be three-phase. RMU shall be consulted regarding the service requirements for arc furnaces. 
(d)  Emergency lighting. When an emergency lighting system necessitates the installation of a separate meter, service drop, or other optional service facilities, RMU will furnish such facilities in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.078) 
Sec. 98-249. - Optional or nonstandard facilities. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in the rate: 
(1)  RMU will furnish as a standard installation the facilities adequate to supply service at a single point of delivery to a normal load equal to the maximum 15-minute demand of the customer, at a power factor of not less than 85 percent lagging; 
(2)  Each such installation shall include, where necessary, facilities for one standard transformation; and 
(3)  RMU will furnish as a standard metering installation the meters adequate to measure at a single point of delivery the demand and energy consumption of the entire premises, the type of such meters to be determined by RMU's standard practice. 
(b)  In the event service facilities in addition to or different from a standard installation are requested by the customer or are required to serve the customer's load, RMU shall furnish, install, and maintain such facilities, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The type, extent and location of such service facilities shall be determined by agreement between RMU and the customer. 
(2)  Such service facilities shall be the property of RMU. 
(3)  If the amount by which the estimated cost of the facilities installed exceeds the cost of a standard installation is more than $100.00, the customer shall pay RMU such amount at the time of installation including taxes, if any, except: 
a.  In the case of meters, the customer shall pay monthly rentals in accordance with the provisions of RMU's current practice; and 
b.  In the case of transformers and any other equipment which RMU may elect to provide on a rental basis (in lieu of which the customer may provide, install, and maintain his own facilities for the same purpose), the customer shall pay a rental equal to the amount by which RMU's standard rental charges for the equipment installed exceed those for the equipment included in a standard installation. Whenever an installation is made which requires a rental payment, or when there is a change in facilities which requires a different rental payment, the rental charge for all facilities of the same class will be based on the charges in effect at the time of the installation or change. 
(4)  In case the providing of optional or nonstandard facilities involves the furnishing, installing, and maintaining of facilities which may reasonably be used for other customers, the cost or rental payable by the customer shall be that portion of the total cost or rental which is reasonably assignable to the customer. 
(5)  Late payment charges shall be applicable to all rental charges under this section. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.080) 
Sec. 98-250. - Furnishing of underground service facilities. 
(a)  Where overhead supply would be standard, RMU will, upon request, provide underground service in accordance with provisions of the following subsections if the conditions of such subsections are met. 
(b)  If RMU, in accordance with the applicable subsections of this section and sections 98-226-98-234 and 98-253-98-255, furnishes, installs, owns, and maintains an underground system including underground service connections, the customer shall comply with the following requirements before trenching operations are begun by RMU: 
(1)  Provide such permits, easements or other rights as RMU reasonably deems necessary for the ownership, installation, operation, maintenance and replacement of RMU facilities so provided; 
(2)  Remove all obstructions from such easement strips or rights-of-way including above and below grade rubble or tree stumps, etc., in redeveloped and undeveloped areas; 
(3)  Grade the easement strips or rights-of-way to a level not above nor more than four inches below final grade; 
(4)  Install marker stakes for lot corners and grade purposes placed at intervals designated by RMU; 
(5)  Make the easement strips or rights-of-way accessible to RMU's equipment; and 
(6)  In the case of a new development, provide a document specifying the final grade and drainage of the development. 
(c)  In the event RMU is requested to provide an underground system different from or more elaborate than the one reasonably considered by RMU to be practical, the developer or customer shall reimburse RMU for any additional cost resulting therefrom in accordance with RMU's provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(d)  All facilities provided by the developer or customer shall be furnished and installed in accordance with RMU specifications. 
(e)  RMU shall be paid any additional cost incurred by reason of: 
(1)  Crossing streets, alleys, parking areas or other areas in the development which cannot be trenched in a normal manner; 
(2)  Special municipal requirements; or 
(3)  Rearrangement of or change in facilities caused by changes made by the developer or customer after the initial planning. 
(f)  RMU shall not be required to install the electrical system in segments smaller than considered economical by RMU. 
(g)  Overhead service shall not be provided where an underground system has been established. 
(h)  Where an overhead system exists, and the customer requests replacement with an underground system RMU will provide an underground system on the same basis as set forth in the subsections of this section except that the customer shall reimburse RMU for the value of the remaining life of the overhead facilities to be removed plus removal cost less salvage. If the overhead system includes feeders or other facilities not used to provide service to such customer, the additional cost of installing such facilities underground or rerouting them overhead shall be borne by the customer. 
(i)  If an underground system is requested by a group of individual property owners, RMU will not attempt to allocate its charges, if any, among the individual property owners, but will require such owners, acting as a group, to make a single payment of the total charges applicable to all the affected properties before the work commences. 
(j)  Following installation of underground service facilities, or in the case of the repair and acquisition of a service connection in accordance with section 98-226(b), RMU shall have continued access to the facilities without impediments from overbuilding, increase in established grade or other obstructions for operation, maintenance and replacement of such facilities. When these conditions are not met, any additional costs incurred by RMU by reason thereof shall be paid by the customer. In the event a change in grade reduces the depth of RMU's installed underground facilities, the customer (property owner) shall restore the proper grade at the customer's expense or reimburse RMU for any required relocation or revision. 
(k)  Removal of obstructions or restoration of turf or other landscaping features on the customer's property (outside of the primary distribution system easement strip) for the establishment, installation, maintenance or replacement of a direct burial service connection shall be the responsibility and at the expense of the customer if the work done on the customer's property is required or requested by the customer for the customer's electric supply. If such work is required by RMU, such removal or restoration shall be the responsibility of RMU and at its expense. 
(l)  If RMU schedules underground work on an occupied premises outside of the primary distribution system easement strip, RMU will contact the occupant prior to digging for the purpose of locating customer underground facilities. In case of an emergency dealing with safety or restoration of service, RMU personnel will attempt such contact prior to digging, but will proceed with the work if the contact cannot be made in a timely fashion. 
(m)  If an underground system is requested for projects other than those meeting the conditions set forth above, such system will be furnished by RMU in accordance with the provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.090) 
Sec. 98-251. - Multiple occupancy developments. 
(a)  If an underground system is requested to serve a group of four or more residential or commercial customers located in an apartment house project, a shopping center or a similar development, underground facilities will be provided by RMU subject to the conditions in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(b)  The developer shall furnish RMU a plat of the area to be served showing location of buildings, driveways, parking areas, approximate number of customers to be served in each building, and an estimate of electrical requirements of the project. Based on this information RMU will design an underground system capable of supplying in a practical manner the electrical needs of the customers to be served in the project. The developer shall provide such permits, easements, or other rights as RMU reasonably deems necessary for the ownership, operation, maintenance and replacement of its facilities within the project. 
(c)  RMU shall furnish, install, own, and maintain at its expense all of the electrical facilities required for the proposed underground system except as follows: 
(1)  If it is practical to service the development from RMU's existing or proposed secondary distribution system at or adjacent to the development property line, the developer shall furnish, install, own and maintain at the customer's expense, any manholes, duct or conduit required for the underground system and, if the customer desires any primary service facilities within the property, all necessary pads for transformer installation. If direct burial cable is used, the necessary trenching and back filling shall be at the developer's expense. 
(2)  The developer, at the customer's expense, will furnish, install, own and maintain all conduits required within buildings. Secondary underground cables will be installed within buildings in accordance with the provisions of section 98-232. 
(3)  Primary cables required within buildings to provide service in such buildings shall be subject to RMU's provisions for furnishing optional facilities. 
(4)  In the case of an electric service station, the customer shall provide the pad and secondary cable and conduit at the customer's expense (see section 98-222(b)(2) and (3)). 
(d)  If the developer of an area planned for commercial or industrial buildings, such as an industrial park, requires underground facilities where overhead facilities are standard, and does not qualify for underground facilities under subsections (a) through (c) of this section, RMU shall furnish an underground distribution system and the developer shall pay the excess cost of such system over the cost of a standard overhead distribution system. If there is no developer, and underground facilities are required by the owner of an individual site in such area, the owner shall pay the excess cost in accordance with the foregoing sentence provided, however, that if, within five years from the date of installation of such facilities, additional customers are served from the underground system installed hereunder, such additional customers shall pay their proportionate shares of such excess cost. Such payments shall be distributed among the owner and additional customers previously making payments hereunder in accordance with their prior contributions. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.092) 
Sec. 98-252. - Single-family developments. 
(a)  If an underground system is requested for a single-family residential units not now served, an underground primary system will be installed by RMU, except to the extent set forth in the other applicable subsections of sections 98-250 and 98-251 and this section, and in accordance with the standard charges in sections 98-253 and 98-254. 
(b)  A refundable deposit required for each lot to be served shall be made before construction of the underground system is started. The customer, contractor, developer, etc., shall contact the RMU business office concerning the deposit amount and payment thereof. Such deposit shall be refunded as each residential unit is connected. Any portion of the deposit not so refunded and remaining at the end of ten years from the date of installation shall become the property of RMU. RMU will not be required to pay interest on any such deposit. In no case shall the amount refunded exceed the amount of the original deposit. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.094) 
Sec. 98-253. - Standard charges for residential underground service; charges for underground distribution systems. 
(a)  For groups of single-family units consisting of, but not limited to, individual residences, mobile homes in a permanent mobile home park, qualifying lots in a recreational park, less than four-unit apartment buildings, or a row house development, RMU will construct the underground primary distribution system. The customer will be responsible for furnishing, installing, owning, and maintaining the secondary underground service. The customer shall pay a deposit in advance of construction for the total cost to install the primary distribution system. RMU will refund the average cost per lot of the primary and secondary system. The refund will be made for each residential unit that has permanent electric service and is a permanently occupied dwelling. The refundable amount shall be payable in advance of the construction or at a date(s) agreed to by RMU. Any portion of the deposit not so refunded and remaining at the end of ten years from the date of installation shall become the property of RMU. RMU will not be required to pay interest on any such deposit. In no case shall the amount refunded exceed the amount of the original deposit. 
(b)  An additional nonrefundable charge will be required if the average length of lot lines along the route of the proposed distribution system exceeds 15 feet. A charge per foot per lot shall be made for the excess of average lot line length over 125 feet. The charge for additional cable, on a per foot basis, shall be a flat charge, as in effect from time to time, determined by RMU. Contact RMU for current standard charges. 
(c)  Where primary and/or secondary distribution system risers on RMU-owned cable poles are required to supply underground distribution systems to service fewer than eight single-family units, a charge shall be made for each riser so required. The charge for each type or riser shall be a flat charge, as in effect from time to time, determined by RMU. Contact RMU for current standard charges. 
(d)  Charges are subject to conditions set forth in section 98-250(b)-(f), (j), and (k), which set forth certain situations requiring additional charge. For example, if hand digging is necessary, the extra cost will be reflected in charges to the customer. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.100) 
Sec. 98-254. - Charges for underground service connections. 
(a)  Primary service connection. In cases where a primary service connection is required, a charge per foot shall be made for the first 135 feet of the service connection as measured from the point at which it crosses the lot line or easement line (if no lot line is crossed) to the base of the electric service station. If the length of the service connection exceeds 135 feet, an additional and separate charge per foot shall be made for such excess. If service is supplied from an overhead distribution system, an additional charge is made for the primary riser on the pole. The charges for additional cable, on a per foot basis, and the charge for each riser shall be at flat charges, as in effect from time to time, determined by RMU. Contact RMU for the current standard charges. 
(b)  Secondary service connection. The customer is responsible to furnish, install, own, and maintain all underground secondary connections. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.102) 
Sec. 98-255. - Street lighting construction. 
(a)  RMU will furnish, install, own, and maintain street lighting if requested by the customer. The customer shall pay the costs for furnishing and installation/construction prior to the beginning of the work. If the customer chooses to furnish and install street lighting, which is to be owned and maintained by RMU, the street lighting shall conform to the standards established by RMU or the local code. 
(b)  Street lighting standards used for construction by RMU will be as published by the Illuminating Engineering Society (IES). 
(c)  Before work is started by RMU on the installation of any portion of a street lighting construction project, a plan showing the proposed installation shall be submitted to RMU for its approval as related to RMU requirements. Such installation shall be made in accordance with the approved plan and be subject to examination to the extent deemed necessary by RMU. 
(d)  If RMU, in accordance with the applicable subsections of this section, furnishes, installs, owns, and maintains the street lighting, the customer shall comply with the following requirements before construction is begun by RMU: 
(1)  Provide such permits, easements or other rights as RMU reasonably deems necessary for the ownership, installation, operation, maintenance and replacement of RMU facilities so provided; 
(2)  Remove all obstructions from such easement strips or rights-of-way including above and below grade rubble or tree stumps, etc., in redeveloped and undeveloped areas; 
(3)  Grade the easement strips or rights-of-way to a level not above nor more than four inches below final grade; 
(4)  Install marker stakes for lot corners and grade purposes placed at intervals designated by RMU; 
(5)  Make the easement strips or rights-of-way accessible to RMU's equipment and; 
(6)  In the case of a new development, provide a document specifying the final grade and drainage of the development. 
(e)  Charges for rental, maintenance and operation of street lights shall be in accordance with established rate schedules. 
(Code 1996, § 11.05.110) 
Sec. 98-256. - Pole attachments. 
(a)  No public or private entity, other than the city, shall make or maintain any attachment to or within any RMU poles, ducts or conduits (including without limitation any crossbars, line wires, guy wires, cables, apparatus, fixtures or other appurtenances affixed to or carried on said pole, duct or conduit), without having in place a valid unexpired pole attachment agreement between the entity and the city for the pole, duct or conduit, and without first having received any required permits and paid all required pole attachment fees for the pole, duct or conduit. 
(b)  Any attachment to an RMU pole, duct or conduit which is made or maintained in violation of this section shall be an unauthorized attachment. Any such attachment which is initially an authorized attachment shall become an unauthorized attachment upon the expiration or breach of the pole attachment agreement, including without limitation the failure to make timely payment of any pole attachment fee. Any unauthorized attachment shall constitute a trespass upon property of the city. 
(c)  Pole attachment fees shall be set by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(d)  Any public or private entity which makes or maintains an unauthorized pole attachment shall pay, within ten days following receipt of written notice from the city, an unauthorized attachment fee of three times the annual pole attachment fee for each unauthorized attachment, for each year or part of a year dating from the date the unauthorized attachment was made or, if the attachment was initially an authorized attachment, from the date the attachment became an unauthorized attachment. 
(e)  If payment of unauthorized attachment fees is not made in a timely manner, RMU may recover the amount of such fees, together with declaratory and/or injunctive relief, and costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 08-3658, 3-24-2008) 
Sec. 98-257. - Aggregation of retail customer demand response. 
(a)  The city or its authorized designee is the sole entity permitted to bid demand response on behalf of retail customers served by the city directly into any Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-approved independent system operator's or regional transmission organization's organized electric markets. 
(b)  Retail customers served by the city wishing to bid their demand response into a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-approved independent system operator's or regional transmission organization's organized electric markets may do so by participating in the program established by the city or its authorized designee. Retail customers are not permitted to participate in the demand response program of any other entity without the express prior authorization of the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-3784, 2-9-2009) 
Sec. 98-258. - Ancillary services provided by demand response resources. 
(a)  The city or its authorized designee is the sole entity permitted to bid demand response on behalf of retail customers served by the city directly into any Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-approved independent system operator's or regional transmission organization's organized markets for energy imbalance, spinning reserves, supplemental reserves, reactive power and voltage control, or regulation and frequency response ancillary services (or its functional equivalent in the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-approved independent system operator's or regional transmission organization's tariff). 
(b)  Retail customers served by the city wishing to bid their demand response into a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-approved independent system operator's or regional transmission organization's organized markets for energy imbalance, spinning reserves, supplemental reserves, reactive power and voltage control, or regulation and frequency response ancillary services (or its functional equivalent in the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission-approved independent system operator's or regional transmission organization's tariff) may do so by participating in the program established by the city or its authorized designee. Retail customers are not permitted to participate in the demand response program of any other entity without the express prior authorization of the city. 
(Ord. No. 09-3784, 2-9-2009) 
ARTICLE VI. - INTERCONNECTION AND NET METERING 

Sec. 98-259. - Interconnection. 
    RMU shall make available, upon request, interconnection services to any customer that meets the applicable requirements. Interconnection services in this article refers to on-site generating facilities connected to the RMU electric distribution system in a manner that will allow excess electricity generated by the eligible on-site generating facility to be safely delivered onto RMU's electric distribution system. The requirements for interconnection services shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 09-3878, § 1(Exh. A), 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 98-260. - Net metering. 
    RMU shall make available, upon request, net metering service to any customer taking service from RMU who meets the applicable requirements. Net metering in this article refers to service to an electric customer under which electric energy generated by that electric customer from an eligible on-site generating facility owned by that customer and, under some circumstances, delivered onto RMU's electric distribution system, may be used to offset electric energy provided by RMU to the electric customer. The requirements for net metering service shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 09-3878, § 1(Exh. A), 12-14-2009) 
Sec. 98-261. - Eligible on-site generating facilities. 
    For purposes of this article an eligible on-site generating facility shall be defined as a renewable generating facility such as a photovoltaic facility or small wind turbines. Other forms of renewable generation, such as sources fueled by landfill methane, fuel cells, or micro turbines by renewable fuels shall be considered on a case by case basis. In all cases, facilities interconnected must be deemed to be renewable to in order to be eligible. 
(Ord. No. 09-3878, § 1(Exh. A), 12-14-2009) 
Chapter 102 - VEGETATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 102-1-102-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREES AND SHRUBS 

Sec. 102-31. - Permit for planting tree or shrub in public place. 
(a)  Required. It is unlawful to plant any tree or bush in any public street, parkway or other public place without having obtained a permit therefor, the fee for which shall be established by resolution by the council from time to time. 
(b)  Application; issuance. Applications for the permit required by subsection (a) of this section shall be made to the building division and referred by such division to the director of public works before issuance. All trees and shrubs so planted shall be placed subject to the direction and approval of the director. 
(Code 1996, §§ 12.50.010, 12.50.020) 
Sec. 102-32. - Permit for removing tree or shrub in public place. 
    It is unlawful to remove or cut down any tree or shrub in any public place, without having obtained a permit therefor, the fee for which shall be such amount as established by the council by resolution from time to time. Applications for such permits shall be made to and approved by the department of public works. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.030) 
Sec. 102-33. - Injuring tree or shrub in public place. 
    It is unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted or growing in any public place. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.040) 
Sec. 102-34. - Attaching advertisement or notice to tree or shrub in public place. 
    It is unlawful to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any public place. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.050) 
Sec. 102-35. - Trees or shrubs overhanging or liable to fall on street, other public place, or otherwise posing a safety concern to the public. 
(a)  Trimming required. 
(1)  Any tree or shrub which hangs over any sidewalk, street or other public place in the city in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises abutting or of the premises on which such tree or shrub grows so that the obstruction shall cease. 
(2)  Any tree or limb of a tree which has become likely to fall on or across any public way or place, or which has become likely to fall on or across public property shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which such tree grows or stands. 
(3)  Any dead bush or shrub located upon private property must be removed and disposed of by the property owner. For the purposes of this section, a bush or shrub is considered dead if. during the soring or summer months, more than 50 percent of the leaves or needles are missing from the limbs or have turned brown in color. 
(b)  Trimming by city. The director of public works may trim any tree or shrub or remove any such tree or branch thereof so that the obstruction or danger to traffic or passage shall be done away with. 
(Code 1996, §§ 12.50.060, 12.50.070; Ord. No. 18-4935 , § 2, 11-26-2018) 
Sec. 102-36. - Attaching wire or rope to tree or shrub in public place. 
    It is unlawful to attach any wire or rope to any tree or shrub in any public street, parkway or other public place without the permission of the department of public works. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.080) 
Sec. 102-37. - Trimming of trees and shrubs near poles and wires. 
    Any person who maintains poles or wires in the streets, alleys or other public places shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles free from and away from any trees and shrubs in such places as far as may be possible, and shall keep all such trees and shrubs near such wires and poles properly trimmed, subject to supervision of the director of utilities or his agent, so that no injury shall be done either to the poles or wires or to the shrubs and trees by their contact. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.090) 
Sec. 102-38. - Damage from leaking gas pipes. 
    Any person maintaining any gas pipe in the city shall keep such pipe free from leaks so that no injury shall be done thereby to any trees or shrubs. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.100) 
Sec. 102-39. - Damage from excavations. 
    In making excavations in streets or other public places proper care shall be taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub wherever possible. 
(Code 1996, § 12.50.110) 
Chapter 106 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 106-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Limousine shall mean any vehicle used for the transportation of persons when the payment is not based on a meter charge but is prearranged for a designated destination. 
    Taxicab shall mean any vehicle intended to be used for the transportation of persons when the payment is usually based and recorded as a taxi meter charge between a point of origin and a destination. 
(Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-2. - Operation of taxicab or limousine business. 
    No person, firm or entity shall operate a taxicab or limousine business within the city except in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Without limiting the applicability of any other remedies, the city shall have the right to an injunction to restrain or enjoin any violation, or threatened violation, of this chapter, and in such event, to recover its costs and reasonable attorney's fees in addition to any other relief obtained. 
(Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Secs. 106-3-106-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 

Sec. 106-31. - Required; number of licenses. 
    It is unlawful to conduct or operate a taxicab or limousine business without having first obtained a license therefor as herein provided. There shall be issued in the city not more than three taxicab licenses and not more than three limousine licenses. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.010; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-32. - Application. 
    Applications for the license required by section 106-31 shall be made, in writing, to the city clerk. Each application shall state thereon the name, business telephone number and the address of the place of business of the applicant, the number of vehicles to be operated, and the number of drivers to be employed. Such application shall also state the make, model and present title, license and serial number of each vehicle to be operated, and the names and addresses of drivers to be employed. Upon receiving such application, the city council shall cause an investigation to be made of the criminal history of the applicant. Each applicant shall be fingerprinted and shall pay any applicable fees in connection with the fingerprinting and the use of the fingerprint in connection with the investigation. No such license shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of a felony. No taxicab license shall be issued to an applicant who is using property zoned residential (R-1 through R-5) as his place of business. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.020; Ord. No. 05-3335, § 5.50.020, 7-11-2005; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-33. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for the license required by section 106-61 shall be as provided in section 26-44. Whenever a licensee adds to the number of vehicles, or changes the drivers in his employ, he shall notify the city clerk, in writing, of such change. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.030; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Secs. 106-34-106-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MAINTENANCE AND CONDUCT 

Sec. 106-41. - Vehicle equipment and maintenance; safety test; certificate. 
    Every taxicab and limousine licensed under this chapter shall at all times be in compliance with all applicable permit, license and inspection requirements of the state. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.040; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-42. - Owner's name and vehicle number to be shown on vehicles. 
    The name of the owner of a taxicab shall be printed or painted in a prominent place on the right-hand side of the vehicle, in letters at least two inches high; and if any licensee operates more than one such vehicle, such vehicle shall be numbered, with figures not less than two inches high; but no two vehicles operated by the same licensee shall bear the same number. The names and numbers shall be of such size and color as to be readily visible from a distance of 25 feet. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.050; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-43. - Register of drivers. 
    Each person licensed under the provisions of this article to conduct or engage in a taxicab business in the city shall keep a register showing the name and address of every driver of a taxicab in his employ. A copy of such register shall be filed with the chief of police and updated promptly as changes are made. Prior to employing any driver to operate a taxi within the corporate limits of the city, the applicant shall provide the name and address of the driver to the chief of police, who shall conduct a background check on the driver as soon as practicable. No driver shall be employed to operate a taxi within the corporate limits of the city until the completion of the background check. No driver shall be employed to operate a taxi within the corporate limits of the city whose criminal history or driving record indicates unfitness for the position. The chief of police shall make a written determination of fitness based upon the results of the background check. Any adverse determination by the chief of police may be appealed by the applicant to the city manager within seven days of receipt of the adverse determination. All appeals shall be in writing. The city manager's decision on the appeal shall be made in writing within seven days after receipt of the appeal. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.060; Ord. No. 05-3335, § 5.50.060, 7-11-2005; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-44. - Posting of taxicab rates of fare. 
    Each taxicab in service must have the current fare rates charged by the operator posted both upon the passenger window and inside the passenger compartment of the cab in print which can be read from a distance of at least four feet. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.070; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-45. - Receipt for fare. 
    Any passenger paying a taxicab or limousine fare is entitled to a receipt showing the amount paid. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.080; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-46. - Right of driver to demand advance payment. 
    Every owner or driver of a taxicab or limousine has the right to demand his fare in advance from the person so employing him or entering his vehicle, and may refuse to convey any person who does not comply with the demand. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.090; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-47. - Conduct of driver. 
    It is unlawful for any person driving a taxicab or limousine to engage in any conduct constituting disorderly conduct while so occupied or while in charge of a vehicle, or drink any intoxicating liquor at such times. It is unlawful for any such driver to use "obscene," as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-20, language. 
(Code 1996, § 5.50.120; Ord. No. 08-3677, § 1, 5-12-2008) 
Sec. 106-48. - Delivery of alcoholic liquor prohibited.
